description:
Do not be confused.  This is not a cigar shop.
It is a restaurant and bar with old school
charm.

The food here is a combination of sandwiches salad as panini with a few pastas and pizzas. My go to: The meatball served on foggacia.  This sandwich is the bar with other meatballs should be judged.    
Also on the table were a couple of salads and a eggplant panini.  All plates cleaned. Caesar legit with anchovies.

This ambiance is shabby casual.  Outdoor seating.  The toilet room has A bit of old world charm.  A bit rustic

To drink.  Full bar, yes hipsters there are a few local ipas 
And full espresso bar
author: Phil N.

description:
We stopped in here at 10:59 pm (they close at 11) and the bartenders still warmly greeted us and offered a drink. I hate doing BC they were closed and I'm sure he had plans to get to for his weekend but he really didn't mind and even served the couple who walked in behind us cappuccinos. 

They stop serving dinner at 10:30 but had delicious desserts at the counter to tie you over. All taps are California based and the two ipas go perfectly with the lemon bundt cake. They suggested open restaurants in the area that served later as well as must see hot spots.

Bonus-they have beautiful view of the iconic Saints Peter and Paul Catholic Church that's even better lit up at night. 

His recs: Kennedy's for Indian food (open until 1) and the Saloon. 

Can't wait to come back for a proper meal! Thank you for the hospitality Mario's!
author: Andrea V.

description:
Okay, I'll admit it's been a few years since I've been to Mario's but that doesn't change the fact that I LOVE this place. A friend recently asked for dining recommendations in SF and this was the first place that came to mind. 

The Meatball Sandwich is probably one of the BEST meatball sandwiches I've ever had the joy of scarfing down. I don't know what it is about it but my God I think about that sandwich all the time. 

The Resturant itself if a bit small so I wouldn't head here with a party of 6 or more, but if it's just you and one or two others this is the place to be. Inside the decor is amazing, you feel as if you've stepped into another universe. Unfortunately, I don't have any photos of the food because I've always been too hungry to even stop and pull out my camera.  

Mario's is close to City Lights Booksellers, a total bonus if you ask me. 
Drop in, try the Meatball Sandwich, pretend you're in Italy for a little while and leave satisfied.
author: Ashlee P.

description:
This place is a classic !!!
So San Francisco , so old school North Beach 
And w a flavor of Europe .
Small , quaint , chill , warm & so darn delicious !
I love the breaded eggplant and the chicken cutlet sandwiches .
Simply the best !
Great to share and have 1/2 of each .
Comes w the best marinara sauce & the grilled focaccia , forget about it !!
Wonderful service , fantastic coffee .
It's the only place I order my Cappuccino con Vov .
One of the few places stocked w Vov .
Yum
Parking a challenge, 
Worth it !!
Go now & Thank me later !
author: Ellie O.

description: Great service. Decent menu with sandwiches, panini, pizza, salads. Super nice servers. Beer, wine, soft drinks, coffee, tea. Cute little bar right across the street from Washington Square. Sit outside, but beware of the pigeons!
author: Debbie K.

description:
Food: 4/5      Price: 3.5/5      Service: 4/5       Ambience: 5/5

A cute, historic little corner cafe in SF Little Italy that's full of history. The cafe was very comfortable. Although the tables were small and the seats were tight, it adds on to the ambience - as if you're in another country. We got some Latte and Mocha, both of which were great. Freshly brewed, and perfect for the afternoon.

Ordered:
* Latte ($4.50)
* Mocha ($5)
author: Victoria L.

description:
Let me just start by saying I still have dreams of the Grilled Chicken 2 sandwich. Dreams! It was that good. I'm lactose intolerant but said eff it, I want the whole thing, which was not a disappointing decision. The chicken was cooked perfectly and paired just right. I could write this entire review about that sandwich. 

But I won't because the shop itself is great too! The interior is decorated quite kitschy with lots of signs and posters but it works. I think it brings the whole shop feel together and makes the environment feel very unique. Definitely a great hangout spot or a place to bring a date.

Our servers were really friendly too and were attentive to my party by keeping the wine coming as well. My only regret is not getting the delicious desserts that the people around us were having because they looked so good. Looks like I'll have to come back.
author: Stephen P.

description:
Try anything,  you'll go nuts how good this place is! 
This is just filler comments...
author: Tif B.

description:
I was here with my mother and girlfriend here December 28th but I'm writing this now because it's almost the end of my vegan diet right now and I CANT stop wishing I could fly up and come here! 

We had been in the city for a day trip and decided to go to Tony's down the street that yelp had suggested. It was an hour long wait, so we decided to stop for coffee while we waited and decided to stop into Mario's while we waited. We sat at the bar and ordered drinks and noticed the chef just a few feet away from us cooking and sending things out. When we went to Tony's, we discovered that it was from a small chain that we already frequented in Sacramento, so we decided to head back to Mario's and took the seats we had before. 

We ended up getting the sausage and margherita pizza as well as the meatball sandwich. The chef put it right in front of us as he pulled it out of the oven. Everything was SO AMAZING, we all burnt our mouths but it was worth it and I'd burn my tastebuds a million times over. 

Not to mention, the place was packed as we came to eat, and there was only that one chef and two waitresses behind the bar. It takes a lot to work a busy crowd like that with such little space, but they were so wonderful. 

I wish I had taken a picture of the pizza, but I just couldn't wait! I'm counting the days until I can go back and try the tiramisu!
author: Taylor D.

description: Best meatballs sandwich in the city, atmosphere is cozy. An awesome space for a quite date, in the afternoon or later at night. A good selection of alcohol and the service is quite good.
author: Alec E.

description:
The hot sausage sandwich with a little melted cheese and a little marinara sauce on grilled green onion foccosio bread is still my favorite and is still made Exactly like it was in 2015 and when I first arrived in San Francisco 50 years ago April Fools Day 1967. You can set your watch by it, so to speak. 

Thank God, the Creator, the Great Mystery, the Universe or whatever you want to call it, that almost nothings changed in 50 years. Well, I guess the price has changed. 

About every 10 or 12 years I change it up a bit and get it's twin, I'm a Gemini, the hot meatball sandwich. But it's a major struggle to change my favorite sandwich in North Beach, the hip, Italian section of San Francisco with a little Chinatown and Post Beatnik flavor added. Sure, I'm a Gemini, 1° in fact, so I'm changing by the minute. But it takes a lot of effort to switch up and order a meatball version which is probably equally as good, but a guy has to, and should have a strong moral set of values. Hey, they got me through 50 years of 180° changes and I have landed right side up in San Francisco, a Gemini city. And I landed, not on Boardwalk or Park Place, but on Bingo! Yup, I came West 50 years ago searching for Truth and I found it. So, Bingo. No, not the sausage sandwich, but Truth. So a big Bingo.

Tune in for other Sandwiches.
author: Neil W.

description: I actually heard about this place before I even moved to San Francisco. This is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco for a variety of reasons. Their focaccia sandwiches are excellent, if you're looking for something hot and hearty. Their salads are delicious if you're looking for something healthy or light. (hey, it happens). If you like sweets: they have a superb tiramisu. And they have house wines and espresso if you're looking to just hang out and sip on something. The location, inside and out, is ideal for people watching. And the service is friendly: even when they are busy. Of the dozen or so times I've been here, I've noticed that whether you're a local, or a lucky tourist who just happened to find this place, you get friendly, helpful treatment. I like that in a place. It's an "everyone is welcome" kind of place.
author: Jason P.

description: Great little place. Good inexpensive food and wonderful atmosphere. Directly across from the hop on/hop off stop.
author: Carlo I.

description: Very tasty and comfortable. I recommend the meatball sandwich. The marinara sauce is delicious.
author: Olga G.

description:
Came here with a small group and sat outside for coffee and a light snack. It has a casual atmosphere with fine service and pretty good food. This is a great place to relax across the street from the park if you're looking for someone to hang out or kill some time.

We all loved our coffees and even stayed here a bit longer to enjoy them.
author: Kirk M.

description:
My rating is only based on the meatball sandwich, because that is all I tried and it was amazing! Also, great decor and friendly service. 

Meatball sandwich was delicious! Just enough meat  with good balanced flavors, and tasty tomato based sauce soaking into the flatbread dough. Everything just at the right temperature with gooey cheese for a delicious bite, and 2 pepperoncini on the side to add a kick of flavor. Wouldn't change a thing about it.
author: J P.

description: Got the grilled chicken #2 oven backed focaccia sandwich and an Italian soda- great! Honestly one of the best sandwiches I've had. Super tasty. Neat little cafe, cool atmosphere. Server at the bar wasn't super friendly but I can look past that for some great food. Good lunch stop in North Beach/Little Italy!
author: Kalena H.

description: I adore this place a standard in North Beach. Friendly, fun, delicious!!! I hadn't been here for over 20 years and came back to find it charmingly unspoiled! It was about a 1 mile walk from my Union Square hotel and I'm back for a second day in a row for the caprese salad.
author: Susan B.

description: Great for coffee, lunch, happy hour, dinner, or post bar meal. This place has it all. The food is good. The staff is fantastic, and the location is perfect. It's cozy inside. When the weather is nice, there's no better place in North Beach to spend a lazy hour, or two, at an outdoor table, ordering whatever you need to sustain you.
author: J E.

description: Sausage Pizza, Meatball Sub, Wine List, Great Location, Fresh Ingredients, Great Staff, Awesome Prices. I know I am getting annoying but I love this place and in NB it is one place I always bring my friends to go get wine or food. Mario's is old school fun and old school San Francisco. In a changing neighborhood they are needed.
author: Aili P.

description:
Please be advised that this cafe's relaxed atmosphere is best suited for slow-rolling, schedule-free folks looking for a place to relax, think, and/or mix with other freewheeling locals with ample time and a mind for tippling chit-chats. If you're passing through looking for an instagrammable "Italian" quick bite, Tony's Slice House is around the corner. If you seek beer-y fast and furious post-collegiate single white hook-ups, Rogue Ales Public House is on the next block across from the AYCE sushi joint. Seeking a family-friendly themed restaurant à la Fisherman's Wharf? The Stinking Rose is just two and a half blocks over. 

That said, Mario's is one of maybe ten North Beach hideouts worth keeping somewhat secret. As a local I've been going there for twenty years and, thankfully, it has barely changed a wink during all that time. Everything I've ever ordered from their menu has been delicious, but when I go to specifically enjoy some quiet time by myself I always get my preferred solid pairing: a sausage sandwich (the one w/ the lovely Liguria Bakery focaccia, not the panini) and a glass or half carafe of red wine (depending on how long I plan on soaking in the ambiance/watching the parklife/reading a book). The tiramisu just might be the best in the 'hood, but that's how I feel about it--it's really, really good.
author: Kelly O.

description: The bartender was half naked and the waitress was too concerned about getting the rest of his clothes off to pay any attention to the tables. Food wasnt fantastic either. Way too much great food in North Beach to waste my time here again.
author: Erin M.

description: We were in the city with my husky and were looking for somewhere to eat with outdoor patio of course and happened to walk by this place.  At first I was a little iffy because it was a "cigar store" but when I was walking past peoples food and sandwiches then it really caught my eye.  It is open seating and you can sit anywhere and someone will help you from there.  We ordered the paninis with some beer to wash it down and the panini sandwiches were so delcious! You can tell they were made fresh to order (you can even see them making it by the bar).  This place is really cute inside and will for sure be coming back for the food!
author: Christina M.

description: We were looking for a quick bite to eat to eat while walking around the North Beach area and stumbled upon this absolute gem! Extremely friendly staff and delicious pizza make this an ideal place to stop by while you're out taking in the historical Italian culture of North Beach. While you're at it make sure you stop by City Lights Bookstore which very close too!
author: Taimur A.

description:
I went to this fine establishment last night, looked like a fancy place and our first server was nice but then she handed us off to a dude with a man bun. He was not very welcoming, when I asked him about beer selection he was dismissive and told me to "look at the menu" to make my decision. 

My friend was also smoking a cig on the outside patio he came out to ask her to put it out and she took one more drag and then was about to put it out when he started yelling at her saying she was being defiant and disrespectful. 

He definitely could have been way more polite. The whole experience was harsh and put a bad taste in my mouth. I tried to tell him about my displeasure with the experience but he continued to be angry and dismissive. I don't know if something else was going on in his life or if he is normally like that. Regardless it was bad service.
author: Zack H.

description:
We ate pizzas, they were between bad to ok. I would never leave a bad review based on that only, but the waitresses (two of them) were not just extremely rude and impatience but just plain nasty.
Horrible service, I will never sit here again.
author: Guy D.

description: I am updating my review as I have been in again and enjoyed my time much more. We came early this time, right after the North Beach Fire. The day shift worked seamlessly together and the fellow making the gigantic panninis brought ours to the table fresh from the oven. The meatball sandwhich is extremely hearty and the staff was friendly. We took our time and enjoyed our meal without feeling the pressure of the rush. It was nice to see the community coming together, supporting oneanother at Marios and the surrounding businesses after the Saint Patricks Day Fire. Old school SF staple.
author: Simone N.

description: I almost stumbled onto this delightful place, and will surely return. It's busy, small, but not crowded. I ordered the chicken salad, which was superb. And yet while I was waiting -- at the bar, by the way -- all sorts of delicacies were placed nearby, ready for the waitress. I almost changed my order, but was glad I did. The young man doing all the food preparation was unbelievably skillful. It's worth mentioning that he looked like Michelangelo's David!
author: Michael W.

description: A favorite spot of mine for lunch in North Beach. I like the simple menu of made to order pizzas, paninis and other Italian fare. The staff is really friendly and it's nice to linger there for a slow, long lunch.
author: Julien M.

description: Meatball sandwiches on focaccia! OMG!  I buy an extra to bring home to San Jose.  Sooo goood.
author: Ed D.

description: Ordered the eggplant panini and a hot tea. Service was friendly enough, but very slow. Panini was just ok. Very light on the filling, and way over toasted on the bread. Cozy atmosphere though .
author: Ashley C.

description: They have great cappuccinos, fabulous Tirimisu, and the Cannolini was incredible. Definitely, would like to visit again.
author: Christy M.

description: Cool spot - great atmosphere in an interesting part of town. Nice place to sit at the bar and have a glass of wine. Servers were great. I did have a half salad and it did not disappoint.
author: Christin J.

description:
Although I love Italian foods, I am not a big fan of restaurants that are located in North Beach. However, Mario's is an exception. This place feels really warm and homey. It is kinda of tight inside and they have only few tables. I guess that's what makes this place so cozy. Oh, and the food is also great!

I think I had one of the best meatball sandwiches of my life at Mario's. It's oven baked, with perfect amount of fresh marinara sauce. I am saying perfect, because most places drown their meat in sauce and in here they don't do that. The bread is not soggy, yet very tender. 

So, if you are into oven baked sandwiches or love meatballs you should definitely checkout this place. They also have beer and wine, which is nice if you want to stay there for a little while and relax. 

Beware, the place is kind of low on staff and they take long to prepare your food. So, if you just want to grab a quick snack, and are in a rush then this place might not be the best option for you.
author: Ashkan H.

description:
If you want to experience real San Francisco, try here. That's what I was told by a long time friend/business partner in San Francisco.

Great place to grab your lunch, afternoon snack in a lazy slow afternoon. Enjoy the view of the Washington Park. 

I ordered grilled eggplant open sandwich and flavor was amazing. Taste fresh ingredients inside the sandwich, I enjoyed every bite of it. I came by a car and parking was difficult to find. If I wasn't driving, I would definitely have tried some of their drinks, sitting by the window, watching people enjoying sunny afternoon at the park.

Very small cafe, service could be slow but that wasn't my concern. I was just three relaxed enjoying late lunch on weekend.
author: Yuko H.

description:
I have been here before.  It has been on Check Please Bay Area.

My sister is doing a "eggplant Parmesan sandwich tour" (her own invention)

This place was on the list.  We split a meatball sammy and a FRIED (not grilled, people!) eggplant sammy.  

They get their focaccia from the famous place across the square.  The kitchen is teeny tiny. My choice was the meatball, but I think the eggplant was a wee bit better.

I asked my sister what was one of her favorite eggplant sammy's in SF - It turns out that it was one I turned her onto when I moved to SF 20+ years ago  (right across the street from my apt) - a classic - Dino's at California and Fillmore.
author: Amy W.

description: Great place, great food, great service. Stopped in to grab a drink and some dinner. The paninis were great. Both bartenders were nice and everything is reasonably priced. Definitely would come back.
author: Zac R.

description:
Let me preface the night before the night began.

I hopped into my lyft ride and was greeted by the kookiest looking, male version of Edna Mode with ash brown hair, hippie from the 70's.  

Lyft: The last passenger was supposed to be my last ride.  I was hoping to go home cuz I have to pee really bad!
Me:  I'm sorry!  Feel free to pull over and pee whenever

As he held in his pee, we gossiped like two high school girls.  I told him about my plans to meet up a friend who choose this restaurant and he was like, "ooh good choice!  The panini is delicious!"  As we pulled up to the restaurant, I shouted "PARKING! Park and pee!"  He parked and we walked together, looking like the oddest couple, to the restaurant where I sat at the bar and he finally got to pee.  "You are amazing for letting me park and pee!  I really hope to see you again!"  What a nice guy.

Meatball sandwich - LOVE the bread as it was perfectly toasted.  The meatball could've used more flavor
Mozzarella Panini - Again, good bread but the pesto was a bit bland

Friendly staff, good service.  Food and friend were unmemorable.
author: Linda N.

description: Pizza is delicious. We enjoyed sitting outside the cafe and people watching, too. It's in a cute location.
author: Emily F.

description:
Hmm, where to start - hb a short film - https://vimeo.com/215594069
If you're a reader, here is the review.
Coffee: only had cappuccino yet was stellar
Pastries: got go back for them but look delectable
Beer selection: dope
Food: dope af
Atmosphere: dope af af
Workers/Servers/Cooks: talent all around
Highly recommend 
#TyBen
author: BenYamann S.

description: I had a wonderful experience, I miss establishments like this, family oriented with family working , made the mistake of only having my Discover card, they don't accept discover,  but didn't make it hard or a seen or nothing, it was like family forgetting to bring something for dinner, I will from now on patronize this place, client for life, oh an I did pay  Thank you to the staff an Mario's Granddaughter
author: Robert G.

description: Have been sipping Coffee with Vov and an early morning newspaper at Mario's since the late 60'.  You have to try a cup with Vov... it is remarkable.  Thank you Mario for introducing me to it.  Last thing.  The Cigar Store needs to post some photos of Mario.  San Francisco is not the same without him.  I find it totally disrespectful and unacceptable that the the current owners do not honor him.
author: Mike K.

description:
Came to Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe for a night cap with some guest who came from out of town. The night was ruined by a deplorable server. Since the server did not introduce himself, he will be known as Man Bun. Man Bun was rude from the moment he came to ask "do you know what you want?" My friend had questions about the beers and he referred her to the menu instead of answering her question. 

Ironically, considering this is a "cigar store cafe," I was told rudely to put out the cigarette I was smoking in their outdoor seating area. I was told I was "disrespectful" by Man Bun. I completely understand a location not allowing smoking, which is fine, but when the server barks at you and calls you disrespectful while your trying to enjoy your evening at their establishment, it's completely unacceptable. 

Man Bun comes back within a few minutes to drop off the check. We did not ask him for the check, we had each had 1 drink and were not asked if we would like anything else.

My guest personally went up to Man Bun and asked him if he was having a bad day. He proceeded to complain about the fact that I smoked a cigarette outside and she let him know he was short and rude prior to that incident. He charged our cards and said no more. 

Later that evening and the next morning, I tried to call in and speak to a manager. Man Bun answered both times. The first time I asked for a manager, he said he was the manager, thanked me for my concern and hung up. The second time I called, the next morning, he answered and started chewing loudly on the phone.

Very disappointed in the quality of service. Man Bun must really hate his job to treat people with such contempt. Maybe Man Bun should reconsider the industry he is in.
author: Pamela C.

description:
I'd like to start by saying that I've been going here for years and love it.  I want it to survive and do well since it's such a great space in North Beach, but I was shocked by the behavior of one of the staffers on my recent visit. 

I'm writing this review in the hope that the owner monitors these Yelp reviews, so that he will be aware of what this employee is doing and be able to fix the problem.

With the recent nice weather, I went to Mario's to get a glass of wine and enjoy it while people watching at one of the outdoor tables. When I walked into the Cafe, the guy that primarily prepares the food asked me what I'd like and if I'd like to see a menu. I told him that I didn't need a menu and just wanted a glass of Chianti.  He poured the wine, and I gave him a $20 bill.  i thought it was weird that he didn't tell me how much the wine was, but I figured that he would be honest about what he charged me and that he would give me a receipt. 

I took a sip of my wine while waiting for my change, and when he handed me the change (without a receipt by the way), it was only $1.25 in change. He then walked into the kitchen to work on food. That's $18.75 for a basic glass of wine. Only the most super overpriced upscale restaurants have the audacity to charge those prices.  

I grabbed a menu which clearly indicated that a glass of Chianti was $8.  The kitchen guy kept himself busy in the kitchen and ignoring me, so I told the waiter that i only got $1.25 in change when i gave a $20 bill for a glass of wine. The kitchen guy was listening in by this point. The waiter looked at the kitchen guy with a frustrated and angry look, and just grabbed a $10 bill out of the register and gave it to me.  The kitchen guy looked meekly at the waiter and then me and pretended that it was an accident.  

Sure it's hard to prove exactly the intent, but all I can say is that he had the guilty look of someone who had been caught. Frankly, I believe this guy thought he could get away with it since i hadn't looked at the menu for the prices, he didn't bother giving me a receipt (receipts are a normal practice for this place), and he probably thought that I was a tech guy that didn't care about money.  It's probably not the first time that he's done it.

I hope the owner sees this review and works to fix this and keep it from happening again.  If this guy is willing to rip off a customer, he's probably stealing from you too.
author: Lee H.

description: Love this place - I used to live a block away on Stockton street, and always loved their oven baked sandos .  This is a great place for a bite and a peroni on tap - must stop in north beach
author: Claus F.

description: I have gone once to Marios and enjoyed my food. My finance love his meatball sandwich. I wish my lasagna had more cheese but not sure if it's traditional to have more cheese. The ingredients seemed fresh and service was decent. Hope to go again sometime and try some new dishes.
author: MJ L.

description: I've been coming here for years with my family and the food is still it's strongest aspect. The interiors are also perfect. But the music is so freaking loud and borderline abusive. It totally bummed me out. Sit outside if you can.
author: Max B.

description: Focaccias are really good but service is TERRIBLE! The waitresses were super rude, tossing the menus at us. They are inattentive and snobby. If you want to come, expect to wait for a long time to receive unfriendly service.
author: Birce G.

description:
After a trek through Chinatown and some noontime beers at Rogue across the street, I was jonesing for a fresh caprese. The bartender suggested Mario's as an industry fave so we headed over and found two seats at the bar. Most options were hot, either panini or pressed focaccia. The cook was either new or busy, because he seemed super flustered and forgot the pesto on my sandwich and gave my boyfriend the wrong one. 

They were both good so we didn't mind much either way, but we also had nowhere to be and were starving!
author: Lauren M.

description: Incomparable location, nice little beverage list, and the most amazing meatball sandwich on some of the best focaccia I've ever had.  Sitting outside at one of their sidewalk tables, watching people enjoy North Beach and Washington Square Park, while enjoying said beverage and sandwich is a simple pleasure not to be missed.
author: Jeff C.

description: Honestly, we only stopped in for a coffee... But then we ordered a basket of the focaccia bread and WOW, it was amazing. One of the tastiest breads around. They use the same bread for their paninis so I'm confident those are good as well. Legit atmosphere too. Quaint and charismatic. We'll be back!
author: Justin J.

description:
It makes you feel warm and fuzzy inside just sitting there basking in the historical ambiance.
Love this place so much...I'm trying to get a job there.
There's passion in the people.
The food is f'ing amazing.
Alcoholic as well as non-alcoholic drink menu.
Family owned and operated.
It's in a "hip" location.
Long live the Italians.
author: Traci T.

description:
Cute little place- stopped here in a sunny day to get Italian sodas. Wanted to make them Italian creme sodas and was shocked to find out they don't have cream? Um, a coffee place that only has milk? Wtf?

But, place is super cute and staff was relatively friendly. 

If you're in the neighborhood, there are a ton of coffee places- I'm certain most of them have half and half or cream- this is a cute place to stop and rest your feet. It overlooks an adorable park. But be prepared to drink coffee with milk... Gasp!
author: Shalin C.

description: With my husband walking to fisherman's wharf. Need a drink and to  sit awhile. Awesome service!
author: danielle d.

description: Mario's has delicious focaccia sanwiches and the best espresso in north beach (Graffeo beans) made from some really wonderful antique machine.
author: Scott J.

description: 17 years since I've been here and it hasn't changed at all!  Sandwich or Panini can't go wrong!
author: Bobby C.

description:
3.5 stars.  

Oops I totally forgot to review this place a couple months ago.  While several sandwiches on Liguria focaccia are $12, the popular meatball sandwich is $12.75 so given the reviews I opted for that.  I thought it was good but not as incredible as the reviews made it out to be.  I learned I actually prefer Liguria's focaccia untoasted since it is softer and greasier, and I enjoyed the meatballs from The Italian Homemade Company better.  Moreover, this sandwich is a bit pricey for the average portion size.  So yeah... overall good but not great.
author: Beatrice W.

description:
A North Beach institution.  Back in the day, Food & Wine magazine put the breaded eggplant sandwich @ Mario's on their list of "the 10 things you MUST eat when you're in SF."  This was way, WAY before 7x7 magazine came out w their first list, since 7x7 magazine didn't even exist then.  I had to mention this because there are so many newbie "foodies" out there that actually don't know that there were lists like this & that there was a thriving food scene in SF long before "the 7x7 list" ever appeared.  Even worse, there are droves of people that use the 7x7 list as the deciding factor on where & what to eat in this town.  And that's just sad.  SF has been cranking out exceptionally noteworthy food forever, & Mario's has been doing it from day one.

The skinny...

Yes, they used to sell cigars.  Heck, the place used to be filled w smoke when you walked in, when smoking inside was still legal.  When the non-smoking law started, they still sold cigars, just no more smoking.

An espresso here is iconic.

They make a mean cappuccino.  It's written up in guide books everywhere.  We're talking internationally.  

The breaded eggplant is just as awesome now as it was way back when.  Only now many peeps seem to love the grilled eggplant just as much.  I say yes to both; let your mood decide or order a 1/2 of each.

Standouts...
The meatball.  The sausage.  The chicken.  The combo (ham & salami).  The turkey.  The tuna.  The veggie.  Yes, they're actually all great.  No joke.  Basically, if you haven't had a focaccia sandwich from Mario's, preferably right out of the oven & piping hot w the requisite pepperoncinis...then you just haven't lived.  And that's their focaccia sandwich out of the OVEN; NOT a panini w regular baguette bread from the panini press.  There's just no comparison.  Trust.

The house made tiramisu is THE BEST in NB.  No contest.

Sometimes the service is great, sometimes it's not great.  But the tunes playing are always great.  Always.  So, just tune the service out if need be & enjoy everything else.  

An institution.  Mangia.
author: Veronica M.

description:
I have two words for you:

Meatball
Sandwich

That's all you need to know. Ever. In life.
author: Lacy S.

description: Wow, my husband and I came in for a beer and decided to stay for a late lunch.  I have to say that this lasagna is the absolute best I've ever had.  My husband had the meatball sandwich...he LOVED it!  We live in San Diego and flew in for the day.  We definitely picked the right place.
author: Deena R.

description: If you're in North Beach this is a must. Grab a house Campari and enjoy their fantastic focaccia sandwiches. The meatball and the combo are both must haves
author: Garrett A.

description: Crowded with a lovely seating overlooking the busy streets of san Francisco. Understaffed yet efficient. We got our orders in under 10 minutes. Courteous staff, sizeable portions. Loved the way the lights dimmed from time to time from dusk into the night. Very busy but cosy locale. The tuna salad we ordered was fresh and easy on the tummy.
author: Viji S.

description:
The server didn't come by for 30 minutes and then I went up to her and attempted to order and she said in a very aggressive way "go sit down! I'll come to you later". Seriously?! Granted it's likely understaffed, but that's not my fault, and doesn't constitute extreme rudeness. I haven't made a comment in a while but I feel so violated right now I had to share this. 1 star. 

Update: I initially liked the ambiance and music, and who knows maybe the server is going through a hard time or something, and I liked the food. I shall do 3 stars.

Update again: the polenta was wack. 2 stars.
author: Raffi O.

description: Advised by staff at Coit tower to check this place out. Glad we did. Laid back friendly. We came with our two children. The tiramasu and latte, capuchino and mocha were great service was gewat. The atmosphere of the place and music were plesantly diffent from the normal coffee shop.
author: Elizabeth P.

description: Good meatball subs but terrible service. It's like a clubhouse for the waitresses. Everyone outside had to go inside every time time we needed something, and she definitely made it known that we were not welcome.
author: Steven W.

description: Mocha was delicious...thick and chocolatey, but a little on the sweet side. More like a hot chocolate with some espresso added. The tiramisu was also excellent, but ya gotta love marsala if you want to enjoy it.
author: Michael L.

description:
I stopped in on my first day back in San Francisco for an 8-day trip to see friends and family. 

I was wandering around North Beach, anxious from hunger. The anxiety turned me off of every crowded restaurant I walked by, until I had walked by the last restaurant on Columbus. Annoyed with myself, I turned around, hungrier and more anxious.

Too famished to be people-averse any longer, I pounced when I saw a table opening up outside of Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe. As someone with hunger-induced social anxiety, it was fantastic to be immediately welcomed by the bartender, who instructed me to sit anywhere I liked. My waiter was very attentive and funny. I had a really nice americano and panini, followed up with a pre-tech-boom bill. I spoke with the owner for half an hour or so; he was incredibly nice and charming.

They really kicked off my vacation and I will make it a point to stop back in!
author: Alisa V.

description: Easily the best spot in North Beach. So many amazing people have worked and patronized here. I don't usually name names and make favorites, but Bonnie and Vannessa are tops.
author: Daniel G.

description: Great place to grab a cold beer, or a coffee drink, sit and watch the crowd roll by. Across the street is the always green Washington Square Park and beyond it the beautiful Saints Peter and Paul Church. On the right you can get a good glimpse of Coit Tower. So visually you will not get bored, but you may get hungry! My favorite at Mario's is their meatball sandwich which is served on locally baked Focaccia bread. If it is too cold for you to sit outside, sit at the bar and chat with the people around you. Even though many tourists stop there, it is also a favorite hangout of the locals and they always have interesting tips for you if you are visiting.
author: Afshin A.

description: My friends and I walked in at around 10 am during Santa Con and none of us were dressed like santa and they told us to just get out for wearing Christmas sweaters. I've never been talked to like than from a restaurant employee. Horrible horrible way to treat people especially as potential customers
author: Matthew H.

description: Mario's is a North Beach institution. If you are in a hurry, move along and go someplace else. There are plenty of food options within several blocks. However; if you want to experience North Beach,  while overlooking Washington Square and historic St. Peter and Paul (locations used in countless movies and TV shows), this is the place!  Mario's makes some of the BEST sandwiches in San Francisco. Their homemade meatball on focaccia (focaccia from Liguria Bakery, across the park), is one of the best things you will taste in your life. Italian wines by the glass are okay but Mario's steps it up with their beer offerings. Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store is a favorite with locals and people who really "know" San Francisco.
author: Beth D.

description:
Mario's bohemian cigar store, is one of the best places to carbo load prior to bay to breakers. 
The meatball sandwich is epic.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Talk about a great meatball sandwich! I come in here every few months and I always get the same thing: The meatball sandwich!

Don't let the sign fool you,they don't sell cigars. Sorry.

But that I mention they have the best meatball sandwich. Yes I sure did because it's awesome!

I brought my dad in there a few months ago and he is a food critic because he's a chef, and he love the meatball sandwich also. We followed that with a double espresso each and called it a day. Very happy customers. 

It's not the best place for groups that a lot of tables for two.

They also have outdoor seating that Overlooks Washington Sq., Park and that's a great place to people watch.
author: Justin G.

description: I live in the neighborhood.Cozy place to hangout with friends just for coffee or snacks. This time tried their  croissant breakfast sandwich which came out pretty burnt! Not so friendly service..maybe they felt we were outsiders !
author: N B.

description:
More like ZERO stars. I visited this place bc I love finding new spots here in SF. NEVER AGAIN. I ordered the Cannelloni, the cannelloni was bland, no flavor what so ever. Towards the end of my first piece, I find a HAIR. I called the server over, said he'd be right with me, didn't come by, called him again, explained my situation, he said it has been the CHEESE.
I'm sorry, I've worked in the food industry, my parents have owned an Italian restaurant since my teenage years, I know the difference between HAIR and CHEESE. Ha. 

The waiter the came over with my bill and didn't place it on the table, but instead tossed it to me.

I will NEVER EVER come back to this place nor do I recommend it to ANYONE. ANYONE!! 

Ps. Their Italian soda's aren't even authentic, but at least there aren't any hairs in it!
author: Jocelyn Z.

description:
Another North Beach hideout. Casual, conversational, small, local.
A place one can cruise by and say hi to a mate. Always a good hideout
author: Juls C.

description: Sandwiches are ok but you'll find better quality and quantity if you bypass this place.
author: Philip L.

description:
I strongly recommend Caprese.
Mozzarella is so fresh and milky!

drink is not so expensive. 
Nice view to park & church.
Reasonable restaurants.
author: Kayoko K.

description:
When you drive by Mario's and there's a parking space right outside, you have to take it. Then you must go into Mario's, grab a seat at the bar and order a beer and a meatball sandwich. They serve it on Liguria green onion foccacia and toast it in the oven. That sandwich is one of the most delicious things that you'll ever eat: the perfect amount of sauce, cheese and meatballs nestled inside the best toasted foccacia. With pepperoncini on the side.

I've also had the eggplant sandwich and it was heaven as well, but for some reason I almost always gravitate towards the meatballs.
author: Annabelle S.

description: One of my favorite spots in North Beach. Great service, excellent espresso, and love that you can order half sandwiches (they're still very filling, my go to is the meatball sandwich) for 6.75. Indoor and outdoor seating, no wifi so enjoy the moment.
author: Christina W.

description: This was our 3rd Italian food stop.  My husband and I shared the Salami Panini and a full Caesar salad.  It was all very good and fresh.  Even though it was just the waitress/bartender and cook/waiter working the place it was amazing!  Never felt like we were waiting on assistance.  Came back later for coffee w/ vov and Tiramisu.  Both were excellent.  I strongly recommend this place.
author: Sonia R.

description:
The food here is pretty good. Grilled sandwiches, coffee - it all tastes good. However, to spend 1 HOUR waiting for your food is unacceptable under any circumstances. 

We walked in, sat down immediately and within 5 minutes our order was taken and drinks arrived. What happened next was akin to waiting for deliverance. After 20 minutes and no food, I wanted to get up and leave, but said to myself that we waiting a while already and the food should be about done. 20 minutes more and by now y stomach is rumbling. Another 20 minutes and still no food. At this point it's basically a joke.

The food they serve is basic. Salads, sandwiches, and mini pizzas. Doesn't seem like rocket science. After inquiring about our food, we found our one of our plates was just sitting on the counter for 5 minutes. Completely unacceptable, and I will say this confidence I will NEVER be back, no matter how good the food is.
author: Yelena K.

description:
SUPER hipster, but a damn good sandwich. 

My friend and I were feeling some sandwiches so she'd suggested this place. Super glad she did. 

It feels much more like a bar than a sandwich spot. And it has a very hipster feel. But I can't deny that they made a ridiculously good meatball sandwich. The meat, the sauce, the bread, the cheese...all of the things!!

So on a nice summer day enjoy the outside seating, or even go across the street and eat in the park. But wherever you eat it, you'll enjoy the sandwich.
author: Eli Y.

description:
I'm pretty sure that none of the words in the name of this restaurant are accurate.  I'm not holding it against them though.

Mario's is awesome because it consistently has the optimal number of people inside of it.  Typically SF restaurants crowd toward the either end of the spectrum of occupancy.  They're either so empty that you start to question the authenticity of their health inspection certificate or so popular that you start to contemplate ways for "Jennifer party of 3" to mysteriously disappear just to get a seat.  Mario's fits neatly in the middle of that spectrum.

Walk in for a late weekday dinner, grab a table and order the breaded eggplant sandwich.  Solid rotating beer selection as well.  

There's only one person making food so it's not a great place to go if you're in a rush.  It took me forever to realize that they make it all right at the counter behind the bar (I once wandered around the back looking for the kitchen and came back very confused).
author: Sameer I.

description: Foccia sandwiches are amazing.  Big serving.  Said is just ho hum. It takes a long time to get served and then for the food to be delivered.  Not the place to go it you are in a rush.  Nice location in North Beach.  On a beautiful day sitting outside is a plus.
author: Malia K.

description: I've only been in San Francisco two times but will not pass a  chance to eat here.  Great sandwiches,  beer and ambiance.   I suggest this place to anyone I know that is spending time or just passing through.
author: Craig C.

description: We stopped at Mario's to grab a panini and wine and enjoy the sun.  We were greeted  by a server who asked if we needed menus. We said yes please. She tossed them at us. We asked "before you go, is there a special panini today" she said "prosciutto " then rudely asked "can I go now"- not " can I bring you some water" or " would you like one".  I have to admit, we were blown away as we had just sat down- didn't do or say anything to deserve this poor treatment. After coming for 20 years , We will not be back if they keep the server and bartender on that we're working June 25.
author: debbie w.

description:
Take note: this establishment is highly unfriendly to anyone just looking for a place to sit down and enjoy a drink.

I had been seated not a full two hours before being asked--rather rudely I'd add--to vacate my seat for a customer looking to have dinner. I understand dinner-goers offer more revenue to the Cafe than patrons ordering a single drink, but to effectively evict someone after so little time and with so little decorum is nonetheless despicable.

Will never be coming here again.
author: CJ H.

description: Best meatball sammy I've ever had! We also had the mozzarella pesto panini, which was delicious. We enjoyed sitting outside and people-watching on a beautiful sunny day. Staff was very friendly and efficient.
author: Tara M.

description:
Mario's was one of the few places I stumbled upon during my trip to San Francisco. I was hungry for lunch and was intrigued by the name, so decided to head inside. 

First off, service was friendly but soooo slow. There were only two guys working and the place was pretty busy. I'm happy I didn't have anything strict on my schedule or else I would have had to get up and leave.

Food wise, I ordered half of a Mario's salad and half of the highly recommended meatball sandwich. The salad was fine, just your average house salad, but the meatball sandwich was great! The meatballs and sauce were so delicious, and it was covered in melty provolone cheese. Yum.

If I ever return perhaps I'll order to-go and avoid the long wait?
author: Julie B.

description: First time here and I had a solid but not amazing breaded eggplant sandwich. I saw them serve up a meatball sandwich that looked very tasty. I'll be back to try that for sure.
author: Nick L.

description:
Been going to Mario's for years; just 2 things to know:
1.  It's cold outside in the shade and wind so bring a sweater.  All summer.
2.  Ask if there's a tour group ahead of you.  There's one little oven and the the "Bohemian" has gone a bit commercial by letting the tours call ahead and the waiter won't tell you that you'll be waiting 2 hours for a sandwich.  The people on tour will grab what chairs are available and the rest stand on the sidewalk to eat.  (Hate to see those reviews.)

So, come winter when the Euro's are back to work, I'll be back to the Store, wearing a sweater.
author: Bill B.

description: Cute little place for some tea. Best thing was the location and chance to be at street-side
author: Stuart K.

description:
Mario's was a cigar store 50 years ago but not now, it's an eatery with expresso, pizza, sammies, beer, and .a few bottles of wine. seating is at a bar and a few tables.

review is of the coffee only.

brew: americano (2)
-full body, edgy,  freshly brewed, 
-thatsa italian!

drips:
-biz looked slow on a saturday morn.
-even found parking in north beach, so rare.
author: Victor G.

description:
Little neighborhood spot so pretty straightforward. No fuss service. Love catching a little bit of the old North Beach scene here. 

I would highly recommend the grilled eggplant focaccia sandwich. It's the sandwich I drag myself out of bed for when I'm hungover - just tasty to the core. Pair it with an Italian soda and you're good to go!
author: Ainslee S.

description:
Oh my!  I was temporarily transported to Florence last night when I scooped a spoonful of their housemade tiramisu into my mouth!  Heaven pure Italian heaven on a plate.  

I've been going to Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe since the late 1970s and have so many fantastic memories of this place.  Every time I go I acquire a new and immensely pleasant experience.  Last night was no exception.

We had a cappuccino con "Vov", their special house made "campari", and the tiramisu and our night was blissfully perfect.

The cappuccino con "Vov" is a frothy cup of vanilla/eggnoggy goodness.  I'm hooked on their house made "campari" which is a blend of sweet and dry vermouth, bitters, a splash of soda and a perfect twist of lemon.

Our server suggested the tiramisu and outside of Alberto's in Florence this was hands down the best.  A gushy, creamy, wet mass of cake, cream, and liquor just as it should be.

Thank you Mario's for yet another memorable experience!
author: Victoria S.

description:
Crappy service. Sluggish workers that took like 20 minutes for a waiter to come by to provide the menu and then another 15 to get our orders.  Ugh. 

With competing restaurants next door, down the street and around the corner, I could have went to another cafe with the similar theme and be served by them the time I got my beverages here!

Tea and coffee is mediocre and the prices for beverages and sandwiches are a bit above the norm, but with this kind of service, it is not worth it at all.

It is located on the corner of the main street Columbus, so it has a good amount of exposure for people to walk in.

As for me, I am definitely not coming back.  There are too many restaurants and cafe shoppes in this vicinity to simply explore!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Before darkening their door, I beg of you to: Open your wallet and eat what cash you find. You'll surely economize and enjoy a better meal.

To those unfortunates who are drawn here on a nostalgic pilgrimage (as in the case of a friend we accompanied) or who have read a guide book shepherding you here: Your memories simply are not reliable (it's true) and neither are paid industry hacks. 

Cardboard-textured chicken, burnt coffee, bland canned sauces. As if I need to remind you, dear reader, this city is brimming with marvelous cuisine. Why insult your tongue with their formulaic, lazy offering?

Two stars for the period nostalgia of its location and proximity to a charming park.
author: Mark D.

description: Lots of history and the building is really old and cool but the food sucked! There are like 5o restaurants in the area, my guess is that for food you can do better. If you want a cup of coffee or an expresso I'm sure its a great place.
author: David R.

description:
DATE/TIME: April 7, 2011 / 1:00pm

PRICE: $12-$18
AMBIANCE: Quaint, rustic, and a bit small. To use the word "interior design" to refer to the mix of wooden chairs and tables in the place would not be appropriate. It's definitely unpretentious. 
CHANCE OF RETURNING: 40%

NOTE: The following review was written in May 2011 but never posted.
___________________________________

A HomeRun took me here on 4/7/2011, and I probably won't be back unless they've implemented some major changes or improvements to their menu. What kind of a place in North Beach can justify offering a whopping total of TWO wines, without any clarification of year or vintner until we prodded further and asked for a bottle. 

[UPDATED 3/15/13: It looks like they might have improved their menu a bit.  Also, since I last dined there, I've noticed that many TV shows with episodes or scenes that are meant to be set in SF tend to show the facade of Mario's Bohemian. I wonder if they think this is the ideal representation of our diverse city. If so, how disappointing. There was even an episode of House of Lies that had a scene with Jeannie (Kristen Bell) hooking up with a musician there. Well, it was a version of Mario's that looked nothing like the real thing.]

In reality, the best thing about this place is its location and proximity to Washington Square Park. And sure, the meatball sandwich is worth a try.
___________________________________


:::: [ THE SPREAD ] ::::

* MEATBALL SANDWICH (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/marios-bohemian-cigar-store-cafe-san-francisco?userid=BwFEjsr9yLqdszAmAxFYQg#Mqqic4utfXnPET9BMSCYhA)
              - [4/5 - Tender well-flavored meatballs with a melted mozarella cheese on foccacia bread.]
* LASAGNA
              - [3/5 - I *love* lasagna. Throughout my childhood, almost every time I went out for Italian food, I would always order the lasagna. I'm not sure if I came here on an off day, but their lasagna was very well flavored, but a bit chewy and even a little on the greasy side.]
author: Asha S.

description: This is my favorite place in all of North Beach. Everyone who comes through town, I bring them here -- the sense of neighborhood and family is so strong, and the food is so great and decently priced, that we keep coming back.
author: Derek P.

description:
After having the meatball focaccia sandwich bookmarked for ages I think that I waited to long to finally try it. Not because I've been missing out but because so many good sandwich shops are now in business. So whereas the meatballs were tender and the sandwich was okay, it just wasn't great. 

I guess if I lived nearby I would stop by more often not because of the food but because of the vibe. It's apparent that this place attracts regulars who banter with each other and the staff during the day. Very cozy and convivial atmosphere.
author: Jean K.

description:
I've stopped by here on numerous occasions and I've always had a good meal. The sandwiches and pizza are just the right amount for the right price and the staff have always been great.

This last time I stopped in I came and sat at the bar as a lone diner with a book. I ordered my food and the bartender noticed that my nose kept running. I thought it was due to allergies. He brought me a port with hot water in it because he said, "This is what I have when my nose is running." Sure enough, it cleared up my nose for the entire day. I'm sure if I didn't bury myself in my book there would've been much more chatting going on. I'll have to thank him for the runny nose cure and catch his name next time I stop in. I didn't feel rushed but since it was starting to get busy I figured I should get going since I had finished eating.

I know this place is small so I never bring more than 3 other people with me max. I like that it has a cozy feel to it that a lot of places these days seem to lack.

You won't find cigars here but you'll find a lot of regulars who just want to have a drink or a quick no frills meal. The prices have gone up a little bit since I've been going here but I think that's expected in a city such as this one and it's way more reasonable than a lot of other places along Columbus.
author: Amy J.

description:
Love this place!

-delicious foccaccia 
- great drink selection
-prices are low 
-cool vibe
-always leave full


BEST PANINIS in SF!
author: Amanda C.

description: A solid casual reasonably priced place in SF is not easy to find. The place reminds me of casual neighborhood restaurants in Europe. Good food, decent wine and a good core set of beers. Super friendly staff and killer meatball sandwich.
author: Bob G.

description:
Eh. Was very excited to try out the food here, but mediocre service and bland food made this a 2-star review. 

I had the Chicken Sandwich #1 ($6.50 for half, $11.75 for full) and it was disappointing. Barely any flavor, no spices, etc. I had a bite of my husband's meatball sandwich, and while it was better, it was still "eh". I really wanted to like this place, but oh well :(
author: Anastasia B.

description: Went here for a quick dinner with a friend. Initially sat outside but soon moved in as the wind picked up. I had the special panino - prosciutto with mozzarella, red onion and substituted pesto for red peppers. Sandwich was warm and chewy, a good balance of meet, cheese and bread. Service was efficient and friendly, and place had a laid back neighborhood feel. Menu options were somewhat limited, but what they have seems quality.
author: Arugula F.

description:
Came here twice after work.

Right off the bat:
1. MEATBALL sandwich (Focaccia bread + meatball) is a definite order.
2. Eggplant Parmegiana as an addition 
3. Cider, Beer or Wine of your choice...

It's a nice cozy setting, low-key with good food.
It's a good spot for a date since the area is prime for post dinner spots like gelato, coffee and nearby bars. I haven't gone here during the day so I'm not sure if it's crowded and bustling.
author: Kenneth L.

description: What a great place, oozing with ambiance and plenty of character. Great location outside of Washington Square. Unique beer selection and good coffee. Food is not bad either. Type of place to just relax for a little. Not my first time here. Be back too.
author: Rick T.

description:
What we had:  

Italian sausage pizza and Caesar salad

We were mislead by the myriads of reviews and high ratings.  We found the food regrettable especially since we had high expectations from Little Italy.  I wanted a do-over at another pizza place, but my daughter refused to participate and I wasn't about to chow down on a slice of pizza alone.  

The pizza lacked flavor.  There was only a traceable amount of cheese and a slight sweet hint that we didn't care for.  The Caesar was unremarkable.
author: Keila N.

description:
I liked the way the place felt at first. I was hoping for the whole in the wall quality meal. Well looks can be deceiving. 

The food was mediocre and the service was very poor. Our server was so rude and not helpful at all. I do not recommend this place for anyone.
author: P. J D.

description: Meatball sandwich and a beer is all you need here! A long standing San Francisco tradition. We stop every time we are in town. Music is also fun.
author: Jean A.

description:
The server took 20 minutes prior to providing menus or acknowledging our presence. The breaded eggplant Parmesan focaccia sandwich was burnt, dry, bland, lukewarm, and took forever to be served.
The music was good, perhaps I'll return and order the meatball sandwich.
author: Z C.

description:
Yummy!! This place is unbelievable. My hubby and I have been coming for years when we are in the city. Try the Meatball focaccia sand which and for the veggie in your life go with the eggplant. 

The staff is fantastic even if they don't acknowledge you right away... It's probably because they are pouring a stiff glass of wine or making you some kick ass food. 

Be a cool kid and go here!! If you dint your a fool. ;)
author: Vanessa E.

description:
Is this the most amazing Italian food you've ever had? no. Is this most amazing service and experience in SF? Probably not. Is this the perfect place to perch on a warm Saturday afternoon, sipping house wine and people watching in the park while listening to mellow blues? YES!

On the edge of Washington square park and in the heart of North beach lies this little gem of a bar. Completely unpretentious and inviting, a two person operation on a busy holiday weekend still felt chill and relaxed. We ordered with our eyes (the caprese salad - which was surprisingly light given all the cheese and meat on the plate) and sipped on the 'house' white wine. The bar is comfortable and the staff is efficient. When I explain everything individually - it sounds like it's 'nothing special', but if you put all the elements into an equasion, it's perfect harmony and a great place to put your feet up for awhile and enjoy San Francisco.

Definitely recommend to tourists and locals.
author: nina B.

description:
This used to be a great cafe overlooking Washington Square park. However, as other reviewers have noted, the 'hipster' staff appear to see customers more as an annoyance. Service SUCKS...especially if you grab a table outside. We waited 30 minutes and still had not ordered a drink. When I went in to order the food myself the rude barman said "I won't take your order  - that's why we have a waitress". When I questioned waiting 30 minutes, he said. "We'll get to you when we are ready". At that point we left.
Seriously....there are too many good choices in the neighborhood - my advice, skip the attitude and try one of the other cafés instead.
author: Fraser W.

description: Had a great fresh ceaser here for lunch, sitting outside on a warm summers day today. Took a while to get seated but that's because the waitress was so busy serving. Recommend this place!
author: Michael M.

description:
No Cigars but great food. They use Foccacia bread and the meats for the sandwiches are delicious.

Definitely GO!!
author: Rew C.

description:
We were walking around North Beach this past weekend and Mario's had been on our list to try out and we finally got the chance to.  We both ordered the meatball sandwich which had been written up all over the place.  When we sat down there was a framed letter from Mario Batali mentioning how much he loved the meatball sandwich so we knew we had to order it.  It was delicious too.  The onion focaccia it was on was amazing and had a great flavor.  I ordered an Italian soda too which was tasty.

We got there a bit before noon and it wasn't to busy but by the time we left it was packed so maybe get there a little early and enjoy.
author: Blake B.

description: Charismatic bar tenders, the perfect Italian sodas, cute little location. My son said it was the best sandwich he's ever had in his life (he got the meatball sandwich). Well worth a stop.
author: Katherine G.

description:
The food is really decent, and the location can't be beat.  The wine selection is a joke, and served in juice cups.  I get that is authentic, but they could do better.  Drinking bad wine out of a crappy cup doesn't work.  

I would give them four stars, except for their shitty, arrogant service.  Who the hell do those hipsters think they are?  They belong in the Mission, not North Beach, which is a friendly place for cool, normal people.  I don't think the waitstaff understands why they are getting small tips.  It's because you're assholes!
author: Amy R.

description:
This review is based on after dinner drinks and dessert. We arrive into the tiny place and there are two free tables, so we grab one and take a seat. Time passes and the server comes over and we order a drink each and 3 desserts. A lot more time passes. Drinks weren't complicated, 2 draft beers and 2 glasses of wine. 

We're started to get antsy, bummed that are incredible dinner out can end like this, but finally the server comes over with....the dessert. Where do you serve food before drinks? When asked if we could get the drinks, the server replied "as you can see, we are really busy tonight." There are 5 tables, so if that's busy....well, we have problems. 

At any rate we wait...and...wait for the drinks. Why start eating dessert when you have no liquid to wash it down? Drinks were the highlight because two of the three desserts were unedible. The chocolate cake was dry and tasted like a cake from Cosco. My ricotta cheesecake was reminiscent of a quiche, eggy tasting and like the chocolate cake, dry. I took one bite and pushed it the side. Tiramisu that my friend ordered was decent.

Server came by about 15 minutes later and I told him I didn't enjoy the cake. He said, "it's supposed to taste that way, it has ricotta." OK, but the point is I don't like it. Bill comes with cheesecake charged on it. I don't understand this, I didn't like it, I didn't eat it, but you are still going to charge me?

Bad service, bad desserts so I won't be going back.
author: Megan C.

description:
On our adventure through Little Italy we stopped by Mario's because we heard they had a mean meatball sandwich. 

We walked in, and I don't know if the girl working there could tell we were tourists but I got a weird vibe from her. Like this was a local spot and she didn't know what we were doing there. Or maybe it was just her being an awkward hipster girl...I'm not quite sure. Either way, I didn't get a good vibe. Since we had already been exploring elsewhere we ordered one sandwich to go. 

When we got to the hotel we finally started grubbing. The sandwich was very good! It was melty, gooey and flavorful. The cheese, meat, veggies and sauce went well together.  If it was based solely on the sandwich this place would be a 4 stars, but because of the snobby girl, I'm giving it a 3. Oh, wellll.
author: Jessica C.

description:
An epic meatball sandwich. No words to describe the experience. Simply incredible.

Love the vibe, even though last time I was here the service was better, I still don't really care as I did come specifically for this sandwich. Ha. 
 
Beer selection is small but right on the money. Love the park across the street. Makes the places vibe even cooler. 

Even love the hipsters that fill up the place. They are from the positive kind ;)
author: Eyal M.

description:
I've been coming here since I could walk. It's an awesome place that defines SF food culture.

The actual cafe was a cigar bar many moons ago, not much has changed however now it's a hot sandwich spot  and cafe. I'd advise you to grab a seat at the bar if there is room, but the old school tables next to the windows are not bad either.

Cruise in and grab a hot focaccia sandwich with a few beers (ANCHOR ON DRAFT) and the  small-vintage vino glasses of red wine wine is nostalgic and PROPER. To complete the Mario's experience grab the best piece of tirramisu you'll ever eat along with a cappuccino made with Graffeo coffee roasted locally right up the street.

After visiting this spot you'll be embarrassed of where you eat and drink coffee.
author: Joe S.

description:
Good for coffee...but the paninis and sandwiches are pretty disappointing.

Add a side to the $10.50 sandwich and then we'll talk.
author: Corbin C.

description: This is a really nice little bar that serves authentic Italian food.  The prices are good, the service is friendly and the place is charming.  We went back 3 times in our week here in North Beach.
author: Casey T.

description: I loved this place!!!  I was walking along Columbus when it started pouring.  I ran into Mario's to get out of the rain and grab something to eat.  First off, they had Kraftwerk playing over the speakers.  That was a huge plus!!!  The server was really nice and very attentive.  I had a chicken sandwich on their amazing focaccia bread.  It was delicious!  I ate the entire thing.  I had a nice beer to go along with the meal.  I was visiting San Fran, and now I'm back in Brooklyn and I find myself craving that sandwich.  When I go back to San Fran I am going to make sure that I go back to Mario's.
author: Marisa A.

description: This place always has a great local vibe. I always get the veal canneloni but this time tried a pastrami. Phenomenal.
author: Alias A.

description: In order of quality: Environment and history was fun and unique. Good food. Ambivalent service (bordering apathetic) - may have been a one-off or may have been pro-hipster aloof lifestyle choice. But the inattentive service soured our otherwise pleasurable experience.
author: Breanna K.

description:
Mario's Bohemian is a North Beach institution.  The tables out side face Washington Square park and are perfect for people watching but I like to sit at the bar.

The service was quick and friendly. My sausage sandwich was delicious as was a cappuccino with Vov.
author: Bumble B.

description:
It really can feel like like Europe on a lazy weekday afternoon in North Beach and we're not talking about the number of tourists. Sitting out in the sunshine at Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe overlooking Washington Square Park is a nice staycation thing to do. 

Now to be honest the food isn't that special. You can get better sandwiches elsewhere but the charm isn't really the food. I've had paninis here before but more often than not, I end up just grabbing a nice cold beer to relax and watch the day go by. It's a take it slow kind of place. Service here is never hurried so it complements the whole kick-back experience. 

Come for the experience and relax, take your time, and enjoy.
author: Jon L.

description: Great little cafe in north beach.  I'm a little sentimental because this was the first place I went to when I moved here.  It is in such a cool little corner location.  It makes you feel like you're in a little cafe in Europe.  Such a cool vibe.
author: Greta R.

description: North Beach delight. I'm partial to corner venues and this place occupies one of the best corners in San Francisco.  The name is misleading - no cigars, not a store, and no Mario in this day and age.  Just a good cafe, with damn good sandwiches and beer/wine to wash it down with.  Sometimes I will spend a chunk of an afternoon to just enjoy the simplicity and people watch for hours.
author: Adam S.

description:
So I've just come down from a walk over Telegraph Hill, and I'm thinking a little dinner would be just the thing, and there's Mario's, and so here I am writing a review while I finish my wine and reflect on why this is one of my favorite comfort food spots.

Most of my old favorite North Beach restaurants are gone, replaced by places that are hipper, shinier, airier, pricier, and packed with tourists and dudebros from the Marina.  Mario's is one of the remaining holdouts, a funky little triangular building with a bar on one side and a few tables on the other, with a great view of the park.  You can get a meal here for under ten bucks and a drink for under five.  It's mostly a local crowd, a good number of youngish hipster types like myself, but there are still a few older North Beach Italians who haven't been driven out yet.

The menu is small and focused -- salads, panini, pasta, that kinda thing.  All of it good.  I go for the cannelloni more often than not; it reminds me of Christmas Eve when I was a kid.  Decent wine and beer selection, and they make a nice cappuccino.

I don't know if it's the good food, the laid-back atmosphere, the drink, or what, but I can't think of a time I have come here and not had it elevate my mood.
author: Sam S.

description:
I never knew about this place until my younger sister suggested meeting here for lunch before we headed to Pier 39.  The cafe is pretty casual and cozy.  Even though the service is a tad slow, still it's a nice place to relax, enjoy the scenery (if one is sitting by the window) and carry on a conversation without a lot of noise around.   

Since my sister has been here before, she mentioned that the sausage and meatball with marinara sauce on onion foccacia bread were the "bomb".  Instead I opted for the smoked turkey & pepperjack sandwich with my usual...an Arnold Palmer.  Reading over the menu,  I have to say everything sounded delish.  Thus, it will be more visits to this cafe in the future to taste the meatball, breaded eggplant sandwiches and the tiramisu listed under Italian sodas.

My smoked turkey sandwich (piping hot and fresh) with the pepperjack cheese oozing from the side and the hint of dijon mustard was yummy.  It was a nice balance without any flavors overpowing each other.  However, my expectation for an Arnold Palmer was a tall glass filled partly with iced tea and then topped off with lemonade.  Yes, the beverage came in a tall glass, but I was caught off guard and slightly disappointed that it was a bottle of Snapple Arnold Palmer (3 star).  I guess that's why the Arnie Palmer was listed at a price of $2.25.
author: Carol C.

description:
Mario's was great. 

After ordering, it took at least a half hour to get our food, but the price, taste, and location more than make up for that. 

I love the fact that you can get a half salad or half sando for half the price. I really enjoyed the Caesar salad and meatball sandwich!

Will definitely be back. They do takeout too, which is a great alternative most of the priceyer, sit down restaurants in north beach if you want something quick, easy, yummy and cheap.
author: Megan F.

description:
I want more places like this  in Boston. It is a tiny little cafe/bar/sandwich shop and supposedly a cigar store too? All of  that packed into one tiny corner shop?? 

You walk in here and see the big oven to cook their pizzas and paninis and to melt all of the cheese that Kelly D. got on her tuna melt. That oven is tucked into  the bar itself  and when we were there, they had two awesome people working, the guy who worked the bar and made all of our food made sure we were all completely happy with our sandwiches and pizza. Frances S. and I both got panini's, mine with chicken and pesto and sundried tomatoes and cheese all melted and toasted together and Frances S. got their mozzarella panini and we were both pretty happy with them. A little on the small side though for the cost and definitely in comparison to Kelly D's tuna melt which was made open face style, and I pretty much had  sandwich envy with that  one ha ha Kat got one of their sausage pizzas and she also seemed pretty darn content. 

A nice quaint little bar and lunch spot that if you happen to be walking around this area, I know the people here will treat you like they are your friends.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store is one of the oldest cafes in North Beach, (and maybe the US) and was founded by Mario Crismani and his wife, Liliana. They serve oven baked Focaccia Sandwiches (and other Italian fare), beer, wine, coffee, great desserts, but no cigars.

Gayle and I have been here on a date, and were lucky to find a table at this very compact and authentic corner space. It's also cool to see Washington Square park across the street and watch the world (including a few Bohemians of course) go by. The food was good, the service was "direct", the energy was exciting, and the decor was homey. In other words, it's a real North Beach neighborhood experience.
author: Eric B.

description:
Frommer's includes a stop here during Day 1 of San Francisco and who are we to disagree? We were quickly seated and told that the kitchen was backed up - a nice touch. We ordered drinks, a half salad and two sandwiches: mom and I split a meatball and K got an eggplant.

The dressing on the salad was a little odd but the lettuce was great. The sandwiches were good but very different from the East Coast version on which I grew up: they use Swiss cheese here, a really different twist. Both servers were incredibly nice local hipsters who clearly cared about the job they were doing and answered our initial barrage of questions about the beer on the menu with which we weren't familiar. 

Very good way to break up the day!
author: Nancy K.

description: I love Mario's. It's a neighborhood staple. It seems like all the service complaints are from people that anyone that has ever worked in hospitality would hate to serve. The ambiance is very European and the food is tasty and affordable. Every staff member, even during busy times, is polite and has served me quickly. If you're expecting servers to bend over backwards, try the Four Seasons or some other basic trashcan. This is a great place for industry folks to hangout and meet friendly people. This is a slice old San Francisco at its best. You're welcome North Beach.
author: Kyle F.

description: A Iconic sandwich and cocktail pit stop while wandering through North Beach. The place has an alluring smell from the years of caked on grease on the one deck oven that sits at one end of the bar. It's a nostalgic smell that always delivers memories of foggy & rainy days in North Beach, where we ducked in here to escape the weather and have a drink.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Initially, the service here was non-existent.  We sat out on the patio and waited a good 15 minutes before the waitress took our order.  She seemed like she may have been having an off day.  Afterwards, we moved inside and were taken care of quickly.
author: Jason R.

description:
A native San Franciscan took me here years ago, and I have been coming ever since.
I usually order the toasted meatball or sausage  sandwich...the portions are are large and the price is reasonable for the City.  Today, I switched it up a little and ordered the hot pastrami which was absolutely fabulous!  If you are tired of having a boring sandwich, come here for the focaccia sandwiches.  You will love it!
author: Deborah N.

description:
I don't know what's happened with the family-owned cafe or who's managing it these days . . . I thought Mario's would be a great place to reconnect this week with a former colleague who had labored with me in the pits of an S.F. PR company. 

Things were off to a good start - we ordered Pellegrino and panini and enjoyed the view of the park. Then a young blonde woman came in with two children; the girl was probably 5, the boy may have been 7. 

The kids got rambunctious immediately, started yelling and pulling on a bearded guy who was wearing suspenders. The kids completely disrupted the place and wouldn't stop. The mother didn't seem to care; she may have been a regular. And most importantly, the people managing behind the bar didn't seem to care. 

It was 4:30 pm. Mario's is not a daycare or a public park. No one attempted to rein in these kids and show them a little of how to behave at a restaurant.

We hurried up our meal and paid. I respectfully mentioned to the barkeep that we had wanted to stay longer but the rambunctious, screaming  (I used different words0 kids were not what we had come for. She seemed annoyed with me and suggested that I mention it to the mother which I had considered but thought could be disastrous and fuel a bar fight.

It's management's call to ensure that Mario's is a place that can be enjoyed by all its customers. Considering that Mario's is an establishment that serves beer and wine, management must ensure that it's a relaxing environment for adults to relax and enjoy the food and a good conversation.

Sometimes if a parent cannot or will not parent appropriately to manage their children in a public place, it is management's duty to step in and gently divert the kids, and help to model for the parent appropriate expectations for their children's behavior in a public establishment.

The cliquishness among the people behind the bar and their tolerance for this obnoxious, disruptive behavior suggests to me that the owners need to step in and remind employees how good restaurant management needs to work.
author: Cat S.

description: This place is the definition of hole in the wall. I suspect it's less than 500 sq ft in total. The kitchen is really just an oven. It's remarkable that the food is so good.
