The meatball Sammie is delectable and the caprese was fantastic. Wine and beer were good too. But depending on how many people are actually present when you arrive your experience would vary a lot. We sat outside waited a really long time for a menu. Ordered and waited a really long time for our food. We finally found a table inside and moved in. Service was way better inside. BF said that there was only one waitress but really I don't think customer service should be affected because of the owners understaffing. Some people came in after us and were seated right away, I'm sure they had a 4-5 star experience. Food was good. If you have a lot of time to kill come here and relax and enjoy a meal. Don't come here if you're in a rush, you'll go crazy.
author: Han D.

description: Stopped here for a couple of cappuccinos after dinner, the vibe is grey. It is a old time bar with a coffe shop atmosphere. The beer comes in huge mugs, wine is served here as well. There is even a pizza oven and some other menu items. It's a great corner stop to arch the hustle of little itally.
author: Dove N.

description:
Oh wow!

I am sitting here beginning the digestion of one of the yummiest sandwiches ever eaten! 

I got the eggplant open faced half sandwich. I wish I'd gotten the full now ( even though I don't need it! ) because the tastes are extraordinary. 

I'm a bit of a food snob vegetarian and a little sick of people lack of creativity when it comes to veggie dishes. They're usually eggplant or portobello mushroom based... And I usually boycott them as a result of their blandness and ubiquitousness. I am so glad that I didn't here! I would highly recommend this sandwich to anyone... Veggie and meat eaters alike. 

Also there a nice view of the park and the church is just eclipsed behind a willow tree. 

The ambiance is low key and the price are very reasonable. The bartenders are pleasant but a bit distant.

I will be returning, hungrier, and for the full sandwich!!! The beer's not bad either!
author: Paris J.

description:
Perfectly satisfied with the meatball and the combination sandwiches. Meatball sandwich is pretty good. I ate the combination sandwich the day after, so it definitely is not as good as if it was eaten there. The focaccia bread is yummy, but it's really thick and 1 dimensional? I probably prefer a panini myself.

Tiramisu tastes amazing! I finish the entire dessert myself. I like how it's a bit wet and very flavorful.

I used a HomeRun voucher with me and there's a little bit of confusion on whether the expiry date has passed. He stared at the voucher for a good 10 minutes before giving me the americano and water. The owner doesn't seem too pleased with the voucher in general I'd guess, so I definitely advice against buying any vouchers for this place. And this is validated by another reviewer's crazy experience before mine!
author: Novalina N.

description:
We're talking about casual eats in a classic setting (see my photos). This place probably represents the third corner of the North Beach triad that includes Caffe Trieste and Victoria's Pastry Company. OK, maybe you have to add Caffe Sport and Steps of Rome. OK, maybe not Steps of Rome because they lick your neck there. Well, not mine, but Rachael Ray's, I think, on that $40-a-Day-Cause-I'm-Too-Rich-to-Tip show. Oh my gravy.

But back to Mario's. Big bar, little tables inside, a few more outside. Lots of Italian-style atmosphere - bottles of Chianti against the wall, a picture of a boccie ball player, those old artful advertising posters you see at Z Gallerie. Yet again sparked by a complete stranger's adoration of this place on "Check Please! Bay Area", Jamie W. and I went to see what the fuss was about. The menu is small but focused - focaccia sandwiches, paninis, three salads, a few pizzas, some lasagna, some eggplant parmigiana, and a few desserts. That's it.

We went for splitting two paninis, both in the $7.50-$8.50 range (see my photos). The verdict is that the salami was really good, and the chicken one a little too dry. But the bread was nice and crunchy. It comes with no extras except for a couple of pepperoncinis - which was a bit disappointing since I never turn down fries. We decided to order the $6 Caprese, which consisted of four thick, somewhat unripened tomato slices with a slab of mozzarella and a dollop of fresh basil pesto (see my photo). All in all, it's a good snack place but nothing much more than that except for a great spot overlooking Washington Square.

FOOD - 3 stars...good, toasty paninis but nothing extraordinary here
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...feels like a good paisan's hangout
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...friendly enough, not as indifferent as I was expecting
TOTAL - 3 stars...the small servings bring this one down a little...also the easy-to-screw-up name with three nouns in a row...make up your mind!
author: Ed U.

description:
Sandwiches on focaccia are the best here!  Veggie or Sausage are my favorite.  A little messy, but well worth it. 

It's very reasonably priced - and always a great casual place to eat and drink.
author: Jon H.

description:
It turns out that this is my sister's favorite cafe in San Francisco, and she'd been hiding it from me for almost 10 years!  Since she introduced me to Mario's, I find myself drawn back here every time I want to sit with a friend over coffee and dessert or a sandwich without having to deal with the rough, misanthropic crowd over at Cafe Trieste or the overly bright lighting at Mara's.  Mario's feels intimate, definitely Bohemian, maybe a little sexy.  It's your secret hideaway in plain sight.  

The cafe mochas here are delicious, rich, not made with cheap chocolate like at so many other places in the area, but something smooth and tasty.  The crunchy focaccia sandwiches are delish, if perhaps a tad pricier than expected for "just a sandwich" (giving me a pepperoncini or two with it doesn't really count in my book, especially since I don't even like them).  There are better sandwiches out there, but these tasty.  

But best?  Is the homemade tiramisu.  YUM.  Seriously?  It's the BEST in the city, even *gulp* better than mine (and I make a MEAN tiramisu!!!  Just ask my friends...).  Who would've thought I'd find it here in what is essentially a cross between an Italian coffee shop and Hernando's Hideaway?!!

I think this is a great place for a first date.  Or catching up with an old friend.  It's not well suited to larger groups, because it's actually kind of a tiny place, narrow and a bit cramped, although I HAVE seen folks trying to fit 6-7 people at what is really a four-top.  

If you're in a WHEELCHAIR, this place might be a bit too frustrating to try to maneuver around, and I'm not sure how accessible the bathroom is, since I didn't visit on any of the times I was here.

Just writing this review has made me think about going back to Mario's for another round of cafe mocha and tiramisu...mmmm....!!!!
author: Amy L.

description:
The place is a rustic looking bar, located in an odd shaped corner, with indoor and outdoor seating overlooking Washington Square park. It's a great local cafe, well suited for lingering while sipping on your cup of cappuccino, latte, or wine (or whatever you like to drink), and enjoying the view of the park and the people that walk by. Despite the name they don't sell cigars here (they just kept the name).

Their menu includes focaccia and panini sandwiches, a few salads, pizza, a few hot dishes (cannelloni, lasagna, eggplant parmigiana, polenta with sausage), coffees and bar drinks (beer, wine, etc.). Surprisingly, they have a lot of vegetarian options in the menu. I like the focaccia sandwiches. They are open-faced, so it's more like getting 2 'mini pizza' (they sell personal pizzas also), with the toppings and melted cheese on top of the delicious+toasted+fluffy focaccia bread (from the famous Liguria bakery). I have tried the chicken #1, meatball with marinara and onions, and the veggie. Sandwiches are $9.75, and the half sandwiches are $5.50. It's a little pricey for sandwiches, but this is an expensive tourist area, so it goes with the territory.

And don't forget to get a slice of cake for dessert ($4). I like their homemade Ricotta Cheese Cake - this is not a "cheesecake", this is a cake that has cheese in it. Let me explain, think of this like a moist cake with a built-in custard in the bottom part. Their chocolate cake is good too.

The place is usually busy, and they use a small oven to make all the sandwiches, so the wait for food could be long (like I said before: good for lingering). If there are no seats available, I recommend that you place the order to go, come back in 10-15 minutes to pick it up, and enjoy a picnic in the park across the street.

*******************
Additional tip:
FYI, if you prefer a cheaper sammie instead (not grilled, no focaccia), you could go to Petite Deli (~$6, ciabatta bread, long wait time also) which is only 3 blocks away from Mario's down Columbus Ave, past the WS park (PD closes at 4pm M-F/ 3pm Sat, closed on Sundays). And while you're at PD, maybe get some yummy chocolate truffles next door at XOX Truffles (XOX closes at 6pm).
author: Luis C.

description: Perfect lunch place, best mushroom soup and delicious paninis. A wonderful view of Washington square park, definitely a must try if you're in North Beach
author: Noam N.

description:
This is review is based on service and service alone.  

I guess its true, but the first impression is always important.

The fine customer service I received from Mr. Moustache can be rated at 1 star.  

Why you may ask?  Where should I start with my list of adjectives, pretentious, sarcastic @hole, cocky, rude, and the list goes on.  

Take your time and money elsewhere.    I hate it when decent north beach establishments become ruined because monkeys are giving aweful customer service.
author: Ferdinand B.

description:
Perfect Late Spot

I have several friends.

Shopping friends.
Complain-to friends.
Driving friends (golf dudes, golf!)
Intellectual/Art friends.

One of my good friends would fall under the Intellectual/Art friend since he is really the only one I can go out with to a lecture-a performance-an art show and feel that our intellectual percents totally vibe.  Basically, I think we are creative equivalents, and then he tops that off more by being tops in the technical department.

After a fantastic performance at the SFAI, we wandered over to North Beach for the habitual haunt of either coffee or something tasty to nibble on.  Since I've been on a roll with the gym and my butt looking better in my bikini, I was loathe to roll into Cafe Greco where my fave Tiramisu would be attempting to sabotage my intentions with a little love from behind the display.  We opted for Mario's.

We've been here a couple times before because they are open late, until 11:00.  

My friend ordered the Chicken Panini and I ordered the standard Mario's green salad tossed with a balsamic vinegarette.

His panini came right out of the grill: hot, melted, gooey loveliness between two crunchy soft pieces of bread.

My salad hit the spot, a large round plate loaded with crisp Romaine, tomatoes and red onions.  I worked out earlier this morning AND walked 7 blocks in my 2 1/2 inch platform sandals, so two slices of French Bread took refuge in my stomach.

I love Mario's for the casual atmosphere and the typical corner where we could watch the people walk by enjoying this sudden turn of events regarding cold SF weather.  I wore a summer dress out and it was nice to have bare shoulders once in a while.

Inexpensive, good staff and hot little sandwiches to keep us intellectual junkies out on the road.
author: Miika M.

description:
I like eating there when it's not very busy otherwise you just have to have patience cuz it's a bit of a wait.  They only have a small oven and it takes time to make your sandwich.  I got a meatball sandwich to go..it came out to be $9.22 that's with tax, pricey right?!!  In the past I had a cappucino which I liked, $2.25.

they take credit card, God bless them.
author: Ann L.

description: This was one of my favorite spots for lunch in North Beach.  During my recent visit, I sat at the bar for five minutes and was never acknowledged by either of the two male employees that were behind the bar.  With that I left and had a great lunch at Rose Pistolas. In the past, the employees were friendly and accommodating.
author: Gary F.

description:
The name sounds almost like a liquor/cigarette shop with a deli..but it's quite a cute, cozy bar cafe across the street from Washington Square.  

Friend and I ended up here to people watch over glasses of wine from one of the outdoor tables.  I wish they had names of the wines they serve on their menu though.  I had their pinot noir and it was delightful.  

Nice weather, enjoyable company, an attentive waitress, yummy wine, and outdoor seating equals perfect SF afternoon/evening.
author: LC B.

description: I was at the bohemian cigar cafe we ordered I/2 hr later the waitress tells us she forgot to put in our order she laughs about it as her and co workers are drinking behind the counter she brings us the wrong drinks as we were still waiting than she's behind the bar eating toast and licking her fingers (gross)  finally our food comes after 45 mins ,it was only a tuna salad and a panini that was burnt we were the only ones eating. So it wasn't busy Never apologized asked if everything's ok. Never going back.
author: Sandi O.

description: Very nice to enjoy San Francisco and have a short break from all this touristic stuff. I can recommend the Mocca and the Sandwich. The Mocca is really tasty and the sandwich tastes like in Italy.
author: 大胡

description:
It makes me so sad to write this because I used to adore this place. But after the last few visits here I've decided this place is kind of shit.

First off, there's no seating. Heaven forbid you arrive in a group with more than two people and have to cram yourselves in one of their tiny ass tables. To be honest, their tables aren't even that small. There's just no place to walk hence, no room to pack four chairs around a table that could easily sustain a small group of people. If there is a fire, you will fucking die. 

I get it, it's San Francisco and space is expensive. If you come on your lonesome or on a date though the space isn't that much of an issue.  Come in with a small group of friends and you'll get some eye rolls from one of the waiters aka wanna-be-king of hipsters, Moustachio ( Epic stache and epic douche ) Anyways, you'll know who I'm talking about when you see him. 

Food is pretty pricey considering how little you get. For $8 you can get a tiny ass sandwich with mozzarella, tomatoes, and basil. That's it. They won't even spring for a handful of potato chips because fuck you. They give you a couple pepperoncini's though.  

I think the part that really irks me about this place is the service. 

I get it people have bad days and sometimes their service is a bit off. I'm just going to get straight to the point here and say the waiters here are simply bitches. No, they aren't having a bad day because Urban Outfitters burned down and they don't know where else to buy Holga film.

They're just bitches.

Moustachio can't hear your requests for service over his unnecessary facial hair. He hates giving soda refills too because carbonated water and 5 cents worth of syrup is a total scam. 

There's another chick that works there that acts like she is so inconvenienced because she has customers to service- ironic considering we are the reason she has a fucking job. She slammed a cup of coffee once on our table and then sauntered over to Moustachio to faun over how large and thick his moustache is. Giggling and twirling the ends of her upper lip facial hairs that someday hope to become as hipster-y as Moustachio. 

She's a bitch. He's a bitch. Food is pretty good but pricey and as filling as a holy communion bread chip during a 2-hour Christmas Eve mass right before dinner.
author: Kory A.

description: I popped in this café with a handful of my students and the melenzane sandwiches were to die for. We'll be back soon for more.
author: Adam H.

description: Mario's is just about the perfect neighborhood bar and cafe, in my opinion.  The service is thoughtful and friendly in a low-key way, the coffee is from Graffeo across the street, the bread is from Liguria across the park, the "campari" cocktails are $5 and low enough in alcohol that you can linger over a few of them without getting too drunk, the location overlooks Washington Square Park, and the interior is a time-capsule to a time when people had the capacity to enjoy a straight-forward, quality establishment like this for its own sake without deconstructing every perceived slight afterwards on the internet.  If I lived in SF, I would live at Mario's...
author: Daniel S.

description: Came here with my boyfriend after seeing the great reviews. We saw a few reviews that warned about the service but thought, well if the food is good who cares. After an hour and a half of waiting (with people who came much later than us receiving the same food we ordered) I was ready to get up and leave. The food came right then and I thought this better be as good as the reviews mentioned. We got a meatball sandwich and a pizza and let me tell you, it was mediocre (and I was starving so that says something). You could go to literally any other Italian cafe in this area and have something better that doesn't take an hour and a half. Oh and I forgot to mention, the servers were pretty unpleasant. Needless to say, I suggest you avoid this place.
author: Molly G.

description:
This place has really gone downhill! It used to be one of our favorite places when we lived in North Beach but now the service SUCKS!!! We had a horrendous experience last weekend.
We got a eeat outside and the waitress kept coming outside but never came over to our table until about 20 minutes later.  She said she would bring us menus but 15 minutes later, we were still waiting (she came outside a bunch of times gave other people menus and took other people's orders but did not acknowledge us.  It was somewhat busy but at least come over and apologize.  I finally went inside and picked up 2 menus, on my way back saying to her nicely "you look busy, I dont mind getting the menus."  She just gave me a dirty look.
Then we waited another 20 minutes to get our order taken and we were still waiting.  I finally went into the bartender and he said "we have table service."  I told him I knew but we were waiting over 30 minutes so can I just give him my order.  
He basically barked at me in a nasty, loud voice "YOU ARE AT THAT TABLE OUTSIDE, YOU HAVE NOT BEEN HERE 30 MINUTES, THE MOST 5 MINUTES!" 
I said calmly, no we have been waiting over 30 minutes, I know she is busy but can I just give you my order?"  He rudely said "WE WILL GET TO YOU WHEN WE CAN!" 
I was FUMING but gave him back the menus and walked out.  Of course we left after that.  
I worked as a barista, bartender and waitress and would never treat a customer that way, no matter how busy I am and especially if they were nice and respectful.
The people that worked at Mario's last Saturday demonstrated the WORST service I have ever experienced.  They should be embarrassed.  
Needless to say, we wont be going back.
If I could give negative stars I would.
author: Jeanine I.

description: I lived most of my adult life in San Francisco, but now divide my time between there and the Pacific Northwest.  Back in SF, I decided to head to North Beach for lunch.  So many places there are now overpriced and touristy-kitschy, but this joint hasn't changed in decades.  Old-time decor, great panini, friendly but blasé and rather distracted service, beer, wine & coffee drinks.  It's small, on Columbus right across the street from Washington Square, with both outdoor tables across from the park, and a bar and some window-front tables. You can still get a damn good focaccia sandwich for about $10, which is a real bargain in this tarted-up neighborhood.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
if it's a nice lazy weekend, strolled around the North Beach is my favorite thing.
I just love it.
I don't mind so much for tourists because I still feel and remember the feeling, when I was here for my first time in SF.

I like almost every where in NB, but MBCC is one of my favorite joint.  
The place isn't fancy, very easy going and relaxing.
This is a great place for beer and little food.
We had:
Cannelloni  $10.50, great hot out of the oven. 
Mario's Salad  $6.50, this is pretty big for 6.50. like the dressing.
Peroni on tap  $5, Nice Icy 1 pint great Italian beer.
Espresso $1.75, I was a bit drunk by the great Peroni, so have a cup of Americano was a good idea. it was great strong a cup of Americano that kept my rest of the day going.

OMG, What a boring review!
I'm sorry but the review is true.
We were loving it.
Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe.
What a Great place!
author: Nobu K.

description: Chicken sandwich #2 is my go-to order when eating in or taking out. I live in the neighborhood and love this spot.
author: Lillly G.

description: Extremely poor service, well if you get it I guess. We got a seat at the bar and sat there for 10 minutes waiting for even an acknowledgement/menu. We took it upon ourselves to then ask after being looked at several times. Waited another few minuted with hope, no menus instead brushed over by larger parties walking in the door. This "bohemian" greeting must actually be more- were too good to give you the time of day.
author: Brendon S.

description:
Situated near Washington Square Park, Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe (that's a mouthful) is a great place to lounge around with some good ol' Italian cooking, a meatball sandwich, and a few ice-cold pints. Also a perfect place to people-watch if that's your thing. Mario's has a certain charm about it that you may notice when you step inside. It's relaxed. It's small. Even the service is pretty relaxed. Don't expect chipper, happy-go-lucky waitresses taking your order in harmonious sing-song voices. Rather, the service is no-nonsense, you'll get your shit when it comes. 

The meatball sandwich is indeed a delight! Melted mozzarella and meatball with marinara sauce on toasted onion focaccia bread. I love how gooey the cheese is (definitely not a clean eat). The sandwich, among most other things on the menu, are priced reasonably at around 8-15 dollars. 

Spend a warm, sunny (you get a few in SF) afternoon here on your next visit to North Beach!
author: Dan K.

description: Killer cappuccinos, excellent panini, consistently groovy SF vibe with interesting tunes from the 50's and 60's. Highly recommended, unless you are a tourist.  Good views of activities in Washington Square. For the location and ambience, they get an extra star.
author: Jack H.

description: Great oven baked sandwich. Had a pastrami sandwich that tasted like it was from the east coast. My wife had the Chicken #2 and it was phenomenal. Would stop back every time we are in San Francisco. Staff was really friendly. Great place to come upon while walking around.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Great sandwiches, coffee and beer - perfect if you're trying to find casual good food and a nice view of Washington Square!
author: M F.

description:
It's odd that I avoided this place, but that's another langley porter story on my girl interrupted days.

I love all the sandwiches, especially the the sausage, meatball, and eggplant ones.
My only complaint is that the focaccia bread could be sliced in half for a filling sandwich.

I love the old time feel of the place.
author: Princess P.

description:
My absolute favorite place in all of North Beach to enjoy a glass of wine and a light meal at an affordable cost.  We always eat at the bar where you can watch them make your food and take in the whole room.  We like the lasagna, the eggplant parmigiana and anything made with the foccacia (it's from Liguria).  

Service is always friendly.  You come here to relax, not for a fast meal - if you want that, please go to In 'n Out Burger down at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Serena S.

description: Came here for lunch today with some co-workers since we work really close by! It's a cute little cafe with a catchy name and I've been wanting to try this place! I ordered the breaded eggplant sandwich while my coworkers ordered lasagna, chicken salad, and polenta & sausage. After taking a few bites of my eggplant sandwich, I ended up opening it up so I can add in some salt & pepper. It was a little too bland for my taste, in which one of my coworkers agreed also. As for the breaded eggplant, it was thinner than I thought it would be! If I do come back, maybe I will try a pizza instead next time!
author: Mary C.

description: Thought this would be a cute place to have a late lunch. Ordered around 2:05 by 2:30 still no food. Table of four seated five minutes after my wife and I ordered had their food while we still waited. Decided to leave, no apology from staff and didn't even offer to pick up tab for coffee and tea. Wasted six bucks and half an hour.
author: Bill R.

description: Awesome sandwich, great atmosphere, fast service cool peeps.  Definitely a go to in North Beach.  I'll be back.
author: A S.

description:
Daang! This place always does me right.
I love the vibe that this place brings. Super chill and laid back, if this is not you, then go else ware. 
If you appreciate good sandwiches and like to accompany it with a good jammy wine or a cold crisp beer this is your place. They brew up a good cup of joe,so quit reading this and go hit it up.
author: Ladybird G.

description: Gem of a find.  Small and friendly, best lunch experience I had on my entire San Francisco trip.  The pastrami was beautiful...
author: Steve S.

description: This is a nice enough little place, but I just have to weigh in negatively on the meatball sandwich. The ingredients are ok (the foccacia is nice of course), but it's cooked in that little oven and mine got singed and smokey, which was not good. I liked that they had a half-sandwich offering ($5.50 rather than $9.75), but they didn't mention the half is open-faced - not bad, just something I'd like to have known. The beer selection was fairly limited. I would recommend going one block over and getting an excellent meatball sandwich (or spectacular pizza) at Tony's Slice House.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Former "Old School" now a "hipster faux school" joke.

Quaintly triangulated corner location with old San Francisco charm.  We enjoyed the good coffee, great food, mellow local staff who were nice and efficient.  Especially loved watching the former Hispanic chef who'd whip out amazing panini's, pizzas, and salads that made you wish you had more room in your belly.  He virtually danced while he cooked, watching him cook was the enticement and entertainment.  

This has been a "must stop" on regular visits to San Francisco.  On our recent "must stop", the waitress for the outside tables was efficient and friendly, but there was this mustache guy who couldn't move his face or serve a beer in the time it takes to pull a tap.  We came again the following day, service was so slow to the point where you wonder if you should help yourself.  Was left alone with our "one" beers long enough and decided to go, when I went in for the  bathroom.  I could've been a new customer since I only sat outside while partner went in for the service and the check.  I walked passed the mustachioed, a gal, and another bearded hipster guy who looked at me without saying a word nor moved their faces.  It was like the hear-see-speak no evil monkeys, lined up behind the bar.  Instead, I helped myself to the bathroom without being acknowledged.  THIS is now the place where you can use the bathroom freely without being a customer.  You don't have to worry since you won't be stopped, nor be sold a drink or food.  They won't dare to crack their faces for you. Bathroom is straight to the back, then turn right.  Would've tried the food (didn't see the Hispanic chef), but since we could only get one beer each, used our money in other parts of North Beach where they want to take it.  Lost its real San Francisco local charm, and 2 customers now.  So sad.
author: Debby W.

description: The holy grail of meatball sandwiches. A+ for atmosphere as well. Among all the great spots in North Beach, this place is certainly a top five destination.
author: Perry D.

description: Thoroughly enjoyed our focaccia sandwiches. The half sandwich with meatballs was just right for my wife and I enjoyed the pastrami.
author: Norman M.

description: My husband and i love this place.  it is very relaxed and has the feel of a place that has been around forever, which it has been.  In a good way.  I always get the breaded eggplant focaccia sandwich.  We have been going to this place since before they had a menu.  the sandwiches are just as good as they have always been hot, toasted perfectly.  My husbaND likes the eggplant pizza.  Together with a glass of wine or a beer on tap it makes for a very easy dinner on the nights we are too lazy to cook.  thank you, Mario's! Don't ever change.
author: Emily M.

description: I used to love this place,  but wow the service has become terrible.  I came in this week and it took me 20 minutes just to get a drink while I was at the bar!   After that my sandwich was completely burnt.  We go in today for a drink with a big group, we were there for literally one minute and the waitress started yelling at us for being in the way.   POOR SERVICE.  It's really too bad, lot of potential but poor service.  I unfortunately have to recommend that you stay away from this place until they right the ship.
author: Prabal D.

description:
I like this place a lot,  Compare to the rest of the places in North Beach I like their straightforward concept.  Small Cafe, small but well done menu.  Reasonable prices and great location.  Taking into consideration the location you would think this is a tourist trap and on the contrary this is more of a locals place. 

The people working there are nice and seem to enjoy their jobs. 
Grab some coffee, a beer and lunch and sit outside on a sunny weekend to people watch.

Go to Washington square park on a sunny weekend and walk across pick up a beer and sit outside
author: Manny R.

description:
Was visiting North Beach today while it was just sunny and gorgeous outside (yes, I am talking about San Francisco) and happened to stop by the window and read their menu. Don't expect something fancy here, just some simple, flavorful creations.

I had the grilled eggplant panini with mozzarella instead of feta cheese and I loved it. Simple flavors, nice and warm... it was just what I wanted. 

I really welcomed the laid back nature of this place. You don't experience the over-zealous Italians greeting you at the sidewalk to reel you in which was so great. Just some friendly guys, making sandwiches and pouring beers. This place is a great escape from the hustle of touristy North Beach, right on the edge of Washington Square.
author: Raina B.

description:
Came in on Friday April 13th for dinner - and was impressed. We ordered a Caesar Salad -- split onto two plates and made to perfection, simple yet tasty along with the Canneloni and the Veggie Sandwich.

Each item was prepared in front of us - by the staff and tasted amazing and a great value for the price. I will definitely be back again.
author: Brian D.

description:
BEST TUNA MELT IN THE WORLD....Seriously, no joke....I have been eating here for over 25 years (since I was just a little girl, getting my first hair cut next door).  

Served open-faced on freshly baked focaccia bread, with swiss cheese and white onions, then cut into "fingers" about 1 inch by 3 inches that perfectly mold (and melt) in your mouth.

I have taken countless other people to Mario's and everyone agrees.....best tuna melt EVER...hands down...

Priced around $12, its not the cheapest tuna melt around, but its worth every penny
author: Alix D.

description:
Not all of us ordered food, but those that did were really satisfied. We had lasagna, which had a bit of a sweet flavor to it. My fave dish of the night, the oven baked meatball sammy with swiss cheese, onions, and marinara on onion focaccia bread. The focaccia, which came highly recommended lived up to the hype. The crunch of the bread combined with melted cheese and warm sauce was a great combination. We also had the grilled chicken #1 sammy- dijon mustard, pepper jack cheese, and onions on the amazing focaccia bread. This one was good too. I had the caprese salad- fresh mozzarella, sliced tomatoes, and fresh basil pesto. This was tasty, the pesto was awesome. Mario's is priced right, the service is excellent, and the food is terrific.
For a more detailed review visit:

http://consumingcolumbus.blogspot.com/2013/03/marios-bohemian-cigar-store-cafe-is.html
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Let's get something straight.  A hot tea and a latte should not cost $7.

Oh wait, it's because they overcharged and I didn't feel like bringing it up to them because we were in a rush to leave.

Just another regular coffee shop with some good people-watching seats overlooking Washington Square Park.  With so many other options in this area, Mario's doesn't rank high on my list.
author: Tori S.

description:
I cannot believe that we lived 2 1/2 blocks from here and never went. Dammit.

Had to grab a quick bite before our son's concert across the park at St. Peter & Paul on a Saturday night. Sat at the counter - me, hubby, daughter. Ordered the half carafe of wine while waiting for hubby to find parking.

Daughter orders caprese and a pizza. She has pronounced it the best caprese in the world - the tomatoes were perfectly ripe, the mozzarella was the freshest she's had, and instead of just a basil leaf, they topped it with a dab of pesto which she loved.

I had the grilled eggplant half sandwich plus a salad. It was the best, most simply satisfying sandwich ever. The caesar was just fine.

Hubby also had the sausage half sandwich/salad combo and he liked his meal as well.

But what gives them the extra star(s)? Service. They were so incredibly friendly.  In fact, while we were there, one of the people associated with our concert came to get some to-go sandwiches for a few of the boys who were singing. They made them as fast as was humanly possible with only 2 guys working the whole place and most of the tables taken.

And towards the end, after we paid the check, they realized they didn't charge us for the half carafe of wine...so they apologized, brought the bottle over and filled our glasses to the top gratis, and then gave us the wine check for the original half carafe. That made me so happy because I wanted just that one more glass of wine but wasn't going to order one. I love it when people make inconsequential mistakes but have the good sense and superior customer service approach to make it an opportunity instead. They have guaranteed my return business by that simple gesture (which they didn't need to do) and this is exactly why I will be back again and again.
author: Laurie H.

description:
Great atmosphere for an impressive (and AFFORDABLE) dinner with friends. Came based on Yelp reviews. I would come back in a heartbeat. 

FOOD/BEER: Mouth-watering. Ordered a pitcher of their summer special beer, a stout that tasted amazing. They're famous for their foccacia, so I ordered an eggplant foccacia that came out steaming hot and smelling seductive.

Went to Gelateria Naia next door for delicious dessert to top off the evening!

SERVICE: Meh, nothing to complain about. Waitress mostly stayed out of our way but checked in on us; I was hoping for a homey, mom-and-pop manager with whom my friend could practice his Italian, but the waitress didn't seem friendly or Italian.
author: Frances N.

description: Some of the best sandwiches in the neighborhood! The bread comes from the focaccia bakery a few blocks over, by far the best bread I've ever had so it adds a lot to the sandwiches. The grilled sandwiches are the best, my favorite is the chicken #1. The guys that run it are super old school and refuse to do any substitutions but you really wouldn't want any!
author: Grace P.

description: Tried this place about four times now and have mixed reviews. The sandwiches taste great, but on the pricy side for not coming with chips or a salad...they need to improved their customer service, it takes them a while to get to you for being such a small place...I will continue to go there when I'm not in a rush, the paninis are that good
author: David P.

description: We stop here every time we are in San Francisco. We took some friends visiting from France here and they commented that the atmosphere and bistro style seating was the most European cafe they'd been to on their trip to California. The food is great and whether you sit inside or outside it is a perfect place to relax and people watch as it directly across from Washington Square Park. It has a lot of character and for us it is one of our favorite stops in North Beach.
author: Sandy D.

description: I think this place has amazing character.  I love the meatball sandwich and sitting outside facing the park.  On a sunny day it is the ultimate North Beach experience. Love it.
author: Michael P.

description:
Love this place!! I woke up this Saturday with no real plans for the morning/early afternoon and wandered to Marios for a cup of coffee and a foccacia sandwich. Reading the newspaper while eating the #2 grilled chicken sandwich (request it open faced!) was the best way to spend this relaxing, sunny Saturday. 

Mario has a very attentive staff and great food, although I found myself walking past it for several months before walking in and trying it out. It isn't ideal for large groups, but a great place for intimate coffee or brunch/lunch time w/ friends. The ideal seating would be the front table away from the draft that comes from opening and closing the door. 

Again, I recommend the coffee, espresso (strong!) and grilled chicken sandwich open faced. The caprese salad would be more delightful sans the pesto sauce but other than that, I've heard good things about their other sandwich and panini options.
author: Lan H.

description: always a great espresso served right and the tiramisu always perfect.  The lemon ricotta cheesecake was not on the menu due to Mario's widow broke her arm a couple weeks ago.  This is the kind of place it is.  I have been going there for years.  Always a treat and the current staff was really nice.
author: Michael S.

description:
11/18/09
I had a delicious foccacia sandwich with grilled eggplant, $6. nice that you can choose to only get half a sandwich. I seriously could have eaten there everyday, that one taste I had was so good. Staff was nice too. I was alone, so I sat at the bar. Sad the hubby never got to eat there as he would have loved it.
author: Liza M.

description:
Ok so I had one day in San Fransisco and decided to try out this place and I'm so glad I did. 

It's a small place. 10 people can sit at the bar and there are about 10 tables. 

There is no back kitchen. If you're sitting at the bar, you can watch them make your food. Right behind the counter is where they prep everything in a big fire oven. 

When you ask for a sub, that's when they throw in the dough in their oven and the break bakes right then and there. 

We tried the meatball sandwich and it's one of the best I've had (and I have tried maaaany meatball subs) and the grilled chicken salad. Both greaaaaat. 

The cakes sitting at the counter were hard to resist but i somehow did.

Having said that... I'm taking a star off because the staff can be a bit moody (not rude..just kinda cranky) and slow at times. I waited 10 minutes to see if they will ever refill my coffee (i was sitting right across from 2 workers at the bar) and then gave up and asked for it. I didn't mind their personalities it as much as someone else might.
author: Asli T.

description:
This was the worst groupon-type experience I've ever had, and the worst restaurant experience I've had. Truth be told, it's one of the worst ways I've  been treated as a human being, hands down.
 
Our dinner was fine. Service was abrupt, but not so much that we would make a fuss. When the bill comes, I show him the coupon on my homerun app. The night manager at Mario's flips. He tells me that it's no good, he'll only accept printed, that I should have told him when I came in. He starts screaming in the middle of the restaurant and caps it off by simulating slapping me in the face. 
 
Let's be clear how offensive this is. I've a women in my twenties. He's a man in his forties. And he just simulated slapping me in front of 15 people because I had the gall to use a prepaid coupon his restaurant had volunteered to offer.

In my opinion, he stopped just short of assault, and I absolutely felt unsafe and threatened while in their restaurant.
 
I'm disgusted that this is the way we were treated for patronizing his restaurant with a prepaid coupon that his restaurant agreed to. And by bringing friends who spent double what the coupon was worth.  None of us will ever be returning, which is a shame because I really loved this place and despite not living in the neighborhood made it a point to come several times a year and recommended it to many friends. I'll never make that mistake again.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Unpretentious perfection. Amazing staff! Excellent food! Perfect location!

I suggest- Breaded Eggplant sandwich, and an IPA draft. Chill, and tip your servers well!

Cheers!
author: Bobby L.

description:
I was confused by the name since I don't think they actually sell cigars.  A cigar store that sells sandwiches definitely sounds like a dive, but this place had decent Italian-style panini sandwiches.  I wasn't thrilled by my grilled eggplant sandwich flavor-wise but I'm pretty sure their other offerings are much better.

The ambiance is pretty hipster.  The staff was friendly and funny.
author: Benjamin K.

description: Amazing meatball sandwiches!! Got a table outside by Washington sq park with a view of cloit tower...not too shabby!! And amazingly not rammed full of tourists like some places on Columbus Avx although that may change on weekends...worthy of my 1st yelp review! Had to write something about this place, loved it
author: Tash F.

description:
Mario's is fantastic! For the longest time, I thought they only served coffees. Then I realized they also served beer and wine. Then I realized that they also serve some of the best sandwiches in San Francisco...!

The foccacia sandwiches which range from about $7.75 to $9.50 are huge and amazing! I was particularly impressed with chicken #1 and the tuna sandwich but the grilled eggplant and grilled veggies were good too.

The panini sandwiches are a bit smaller and about $1 less and still great! The salads are also very fresh and I've heard that the pizza's are yummy.

The cappuccinos that I've had have been very good but the straight coffee's that I've ordered have been not as good... In terms of other beverages, they have lots of great wine starting at about $5 a glass (Dad complained that they weren't using "real" wine glasses outside... more like mini water glasses but I think he may have gotten a bigger pour than a wine glass!).

We stalked a group that were finishing their lunch and then grabbed their great table out in the sun. There aren't enough outside tables but it's great when you can get one! 

I've also done take-out for dinner and their sandwiches maintain their amazing quality as they travel in perfect little cardboard boxes where they can't get squished!
author: Meghan P.

description: This corner cafe has a cozy ambience if you care to get over the barmaid's surly 'tude.
author: Miran C.

description:
Delicious! great service and relaxed atmosphere. 
I need to come back and try more items and write a longer review.
author: Raleigh S.

description:
The food, if you ordered a focaccio was great.  That is what they are known for.  Everything was good. 

The service, on the other hand was not good.  I don't ever remember a waiter scolding me for anything.  This guy was just a bear to deal with.  We had eight people and the place was tiny.  After four failed attempts to situate ourselves and four rethinks he finally came up with a solution that should have been the first thing out of him mouth.

I asked for additional dressing for my salad and was told that there was already dressing on the salad.  I had obvioulsy tasted it and got an argument.  Then he set down a huge bowl of dressing and told me that it should be enough.  What is this guy a waiter or my mother?

Get a new waiter guys, and update you menu a little to accomodate people who can't eat wheat. I only ask for one nice salad.  You have the ingredients.
author: Diane E.

description:
Food: 4.5 stars
Service: 4 stars
Value: 4 stars

We came to the city to meet our friends for Saturday brunch. They took us to this little cafe by Washington park. My friends said this cafe was very old-fashioned, authentic and yummy. And man, it was true!   I was amazed by their delicious hot sandwiches and pizza. The price was about $9 each, which was pretty average in the city. 

The waiter was good and make sure we were happy with food and drinks. I highly recommend this place if you ever stop by the Little Italy area in the city.
author: F T.

description: One of the best places in northbeach to much on some amazing sandwiches, punctuated with awesome Italian sodas. The staff is awesome. Very accommodating and nice. I loved the music too that was being played in the background just in the right volume. Thank u guys for a wonderful afternoon!
author: Mukul S.

description:
User to live in SF for more than 7 Years.
Walters were nice and polite. Location is great, food is mediocre at best.
G-man
author: Gero W.

description:
Fun place to stop by for a beer or coffee.    Sandwiches are good too.

Kinda small, but that's part of the charm.
author: Dave C.

description:
This is a cute little corner cafe! Love the tiramisu here. Right across from the cathedral and Washington Square....

Get a tiramisu and a coffee/tea and just people watch :)
author: Tania D.

description:
This isn't "fancy" Italian food. But it's honest and satisfying. My favorite is their lasagna, an unpretentious mix of noodles, rich tomato sauce, goopy mozzeralla cheese, and ground beef. Salty, fatty, meaty goodness. Sometimes, when I'm elsewhere eating fancy lasagna, I wish it were this. 

The space is small and cozy and has nice views of the nearby church and park. It's a great place to read a book and sip some wine.
author: Monica S.

description:
The lasagna was greasy, the glasses were dirty, and the wine list consisted of "cab" or "merlot"

I think we ordered the meatball sandwich too, but it was so uneventful I don't really remember if it was "ok" or ''good", but it certainly wasn't great or memorable.

I wanted to like it, the location is great, but the actual quality of food and beverage was low.

I suppose if you want to grab a beer and sit at a bar in a prime location it's good. I was terribly unimpressed :(
author: Roxy G.

description:
I'm just stealing this from another review; it's not worth any additional effort:

"Anyhow, our experience was so unpleasant I doubt we will ever step foot back into this place...

And to the bartender with the slicked-back dark hair and goatee---you are a jerk and I suggest you brush up on your customer service skills."

That is all.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: The meatball sandwich was recommended by the 7x7 cheap eats.  The sandwich is pretty good but its more like a meatloaf versus a meatball.  Its a cool bar serving some decent sandwiches and pizza.
author: Fatty A.

description:
After trying to get in a few other places without success, we settled here.  The side door was locked so they can accommodate another table of 2 inside., where we were sat.

We shared the pizza special - prosciutto with arugula - $10?  The pizza fits on a dinner plate.  It was a nice thin crust pizza with a very generous portion of chopped up arugula on top.  The end crust was crispy.  

Hubby had a pint of Sierra $5 and I had the Italian watermelon soda $2.  

Service is a bit slow so be prepared to chill and enjoy the quaint ambiance - not the ideal place if you are in a hurry or with someone you can't carry a conversation with...
author: Gloria H.

description:
I've passed by this place a bunch of times and finally stopped in for a quick bite before lounging in the park. I walked right in and started chatting with the guy behind the bar/kitchen that was making sandwiches and pizzas. Found out they do take out so I ordered up a chicken panini and coffee and continued chatting. The space is super cozy and had I not wanted to soak up some sun, I probably would have stayed to eat my sandwich there.

The sandwich itself wasn't anything spectacular. It wasn't bad, it wasn't excellent...just meh. I did see a plate of sausage and polenta that got me drooling, so maybe I'll just go back and sample that? Yes.

Also, I asked for a coffee and they offered me an americano instead. I mean, yeah, I get it. Same concept, but I feel like I ended up spending more money.
author: Karena Q.

description: What a fantastic little place! Great service, super food and drinks, and so affordable. My friend and I split the spicy tuna foccacia and prosciutto baguette (both daily specials and FANTASTIC), hummingbird IPAs, and coffee drinks and got out of there for less than $20 each. Our server was even kind enough to give us public transportation directions to our next location on the back of a napkin. The other server even gave us some gum after our strange combination of food and drink - much appreciated!
author: Crystal H.

description: Cute place, good food and service is always great. Sit at the bar and soak up the atmosphere or outside on a nice day... I like the lasagna.
author: Traci H.

description: Their meatball sandwiches are the star of the show.  Nice and gooey with a non-traditional foccacia bread that was perfectly seasoned and complemented the meatballs very well.
author: Mary V.

description:
One of my fav places to eat in the city!  One night while on a cab ride to North Beach we asked our cabbie which place he liked the best and he said that the meatball sammies here are hard to beat.  Yeah, I've been twice now and he he was right!!  They are so yummy and filling.  I also had the caprese salad too which was a great, light accompaniment to the sandwich.  It's authentic, cheap, and a great lunch!  I would rather eat here then pay way more for some fancy Italian place up Columbus.  It's way better.

This cafe is so old and authentic.  Tip: take a trip to the bathroom in the back.  It's tiny!!  When it is a sunny day, there's really no where else I'd rather be.  Out the window you can see gorgeous Washington Sq and once outside Coit tower is in view!  Awww, I so miss living in SF.  *sigh*
author: Sheryce S.

description: My husband and I went to San Francisco to celebrate our honeymoon in 2012 and we STILL talk about this place!!! When we were there we went to this place everyday for a nice drink and some delicious food! It is in a great location and the service was phenomenal. When we go back to San Fran this place will be our FIRST stop :)
author: Sharlene K.

description:
Best spot in Little Italy. 
Great people/service and top tasting food.
They have a true coffee machine! Their deserts are made home made from the true Italian owners.

A++
author: Wolf Yener O.

description: A real Bohemian cafe with cool staff! Not a typical cafe...try their cappuccino!
author: Farzin Andrew E.

description: Their meatball sub is not to be missed. Very cute hole-in-the-wall vibe, and foccacia from the bakery across the park. Seriously, their meatball sub is the best!
author: Fay V.

description:
I just visited for 4 hours last night with a colleague/friend...and found this to be a charming little spot. Love it! The place is pretty cozy and feels like your own personal cafe when you walk in....very friendly, familiar, charming...

Simple menu which is awesome---simple wine list, again, no problem. I don't do or need fancy-shmancy. My friend told me try either the tuna, sausage, meatball or eggplant panini....now I usually delve into meat options but I'm a huge fan of eggplant so I opted for that and an unlimited amount of Malbec.... SO GOOD! The bread...incredible, the flavors in the eggplant, wow, hearty.... I tried his tuna.... SO GOOD! WIN!

 ***note, the amount of Malbec had no influence whatsoever on the rating of the food, promise!***

The server was a really nice character who poured our last glass on the house.... don't know if that meant he was really being gratuitous or if it was because we almost finished the bottle... :) Who cares! It was great. 

And the neighborhood is a gem to walk around after... apparently there is a great gelato spot nearby... possibly my next review??
author: Karen M.

description: This is the best meatball sandwich I have ever had. That's an aggressive statement, but totally true.
author: Charles H.

description:
I don't  normally give 5 stars, but this place deserves it.

The eggplant panini was phenomenal.  The espresso is excellent.  The people are friendly.  The place is small and cozy with great ambiance.

They were pretty jammed so it took 20 min for the food to arrive, but it was well worth it.
author: Xavier F.

description: Mario's is a lovely, unpretentious, and comfortable cafe.  It's small and there are a few tables that overlook that park, some outdoor seating, and a bar that takes up most of the restaurant.  They have beer on tap and that always makes me happy.  My boyfriend and I split a grilled eggplant foccachia sandwich and house salad. Both were delicious.
author: Jessica L.

description: You can't beat the adorable atmosphere with rickety wooden tables and a view of the park. Get the chicken sandwich (add tomatoes if you like). Their mustard has a delicious kick to it - watch out if you're a little sensitive to horseradish-esque tastes, but it's SO GOOD! Cheap carafes of wine as well. It's not the most amazing, droolworthy, tell everyone you see meal in North Beach, but sometimes you just want to grab a leisurely sandwich in a really comfortable, cute, pleasant atmosphere. Go!!! Perfect weekend afternoon stop.
author: Sam A.

description:
The sandwich, #1 Chicken, was very good. The bread was soft unlike most places and there was a lot of melted cheese. Overall, very good. 

My problem with the place and the reaosn why I wont return is the price. To spend nearly $13 with tip on just a sandwich is just too much considering the prices at Dimaggios a couple doors down arent much different for a sandwich. I would at least expect some chips or something on the side. And, no, I dont count the two jalopenos they give as a side item.
author: Jared M.

description:
Food is very nice - A little overpriced for the sandwiches and 'weak' italian soda's, but it is San Francisco after all.
What lets this place down is the service - or lack thereof. I realize when things are busy the servers might take longer to take an order or check on you, but today was the final straw. Considering I have been here a few times before, I expected to wait five minutes for the staff to acknowledge me, but twenty minutes of sitting outside and I still didn't have a menu, glass of water or any awareness that I was there. Indeed other folks on the five tables outside also seemed rather confused (this is a tourist area).
Once I did get service, the waitress had a serious attitude - as if I had somehow inconvenienced her somehow. Seriously....she's a waitress...that's her job. Even better if she has a smile on her face. But no...By the time I got the check, I just wanted to get out of there. 
To the management of Mario's: Your service is getting worse. I for one won't be back, and judging from some other reviews, the hipster attitude is alienating your regular customers. Believe me...when the tourists leave, its the locals who keep your restaurant in business. 
Shame....but there are too many other places to get coffee and a sandwich who make your feel welcome.
author: John P.

description: I enjoyed my recent trip to the Bohemian Cigar Store this past weekend. The restaurant/bar/cafe is pretty small, but not too claustrophobic, and I found the service to be friendly and attentive. I ordered the oven roasted chicken sandwich #2, with tomato and feta, and thought it was pretty delicious. My only complaint is that for the price I would've appreciate some fries, chips, etc. any side accompaniment, because while the sandwich was good, it didn't completely fill me up. This is a minor complaint though, because I plan to return in the future when I'm in North Beach.
author: Tory A.

description:
Great cafe on the corner, North beach classic. 

Grab a seat outside or at the counter, try a meatball, sausage, or eggplant  focaccia sandwich.  (About $8.00)
Love the pepperoncini on the side for that extra kick and goes down nicely with a peroni.

Great spot for lunch or a great spot to film your music video like R&B singer Monica did back in the day.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gx9cl-QChyU
author: D A.

description: My friend and I stopped in over the weekend to grab a cup of coffee when it was downpouring.  Unsure of what would await us inside (cigars?  maybe something else?), we both ordered lattes, and they were pretty spectacular.  It's a great little nook in North Beach where you can mostly avoid the crowds of some of the other coffee shops.
author: Mel G.

description:
I used to come here when you were still allowed to smoke cigarettes
in this place. Most of the time we had tasty ciabatta at lunch or in the evening here, overlooking the square. Marios is a cosy place with character, history and patina. 
I stopped by recently and was glad the place still existed. In general I felt Northbeach is stuck in time and has not moved on in the last decades.
Parking the rental car was a pain.
author: Quasar52

description:
The place sells not only tasty focaccia sandwich but ambiance.

We waited 20 minutes for Golden Boy to open and the grumbling in the belly moved us here.  It took them another 20 minutes, but the waitress was super courteous and so friendly that we smiled through the wait.  Seems like a true North Beach place, as she knows most people by name as they come in.  

It's a small place, with limited menu items, but we'd return for the sandwich served by great staff at the table outside facing the square.  Even if the service is a bit slow, it just gives you time to slow down to the pace of the neighborhood.
author: daphne w.

description:
The meatball focaccia is very good - but had to wait 45 minutes to get it. As soon as we got our food, we took it to go as paying $4 / hr for parking just doesn't warrant me sitting around waiting for food for that long.

No one said - your food will be about 30-40 minutes.
author: Y B.

description: Coffee and food excellent, service not so much by the guy with the curly mustache...maybe he's pms'ing
author: Sharon N.

description: Mario's is a great neighborhood cafe. I love stopping by this place for a cappuccino/beer/panini/whatever. I'm not a huge panini fan, but I come here for their paninis. Service is friendly, even though it's a small place you won't feel rushed out if you want to sit there and read for a bit. I like how even though it's in a touristy area, it does't feel touristy. No complaints at all.
author: Alison B.

description:
Decent sandwich - I had the grilled chicken #1 - the foccacia was perfect and good enough to eat by itself. I was dissapointed it didn't come with any sides - fries would've been nice or even a bag of chips. It did come with pepperoncinis which I absolutely love. They got gobbled up before I even started on the sandwich. 

The establishment is quite small so if it's just you and a friend you'll be fine but anymore than that and space will become a premium.

I hear the meatball sandwich is crazy good.
author: O'Shea J.

description: We loved this place when we visited for lunch a few Mondays back.  Food was excellent.  The Rollie Fingers look a like needs to quit his job as a waiter though.  He certainly did not look like he enjoys it.  Other staff was great.  It is a small place and overall, awesome!
author: Jose P.

description: Give me the sun in washington square and a Chicken #2 sammy and I'm happy. as long as the chicken is cooked right. I give Mario's 3 only, only because the quality of food can be hit or miss. At times the food can be over cooked, dry etc. Pizzas included, and other times, i'd say the majority, the food is killer and its a great addition to a day is washington square.
author: Sean MC E.

description:
$15 after tip for a rather unforgettable meatball sandwich that was overhypped as hell does not qualify as one $ nor good eats.

Service was adequate, but there's no reason to make a trek out here for an average sandwich.  Go to Ike's instead.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
It took a while as my order was briefly lost in the shuffle, but when my open-faced veggie sandwich finally arrived, it was so worth the wait. This calorie depleted yelper, who was just a few hours removed from a 4+ hour epic with Markus Schulz, went right to work.

This focaccia-grilled veggies-marinara sauce creation stood no chance, and as I reflected on last night's show, already being referred to in the text/Facebook world as "best night ever", I found the sandwich enhancing my mood even more.

Brilliant weekend. Brilliant sandwich.
author: Jason B.

description:
When you come to North Beach...you usually have 2 things on your mind...1) girls 2) itallian food. Well this place offers up some THE BEST Italian Panini Sandwiches you will find in SF. 

Let's start off with the bread...onion focaccia bread, because as we all know it's the bread that makes the sandwich. Perfectly toasted, flavor pops in your mouth.

All their sandwiches are amazing...but their sausage panini...soooooo good. 

I ended up ordering the cannelloni...which was AMAZING! Their mix of spinach, cheese, veal, and chicken in a marinara sauce...wow...too bad they only give u 2 :(. I was still hungry so I ordered up a sandwich...best choice I've made in my life. 

DEFINITELY RECOMMEND COMING HERE!!!
author: Nick C.

description: Love the meatball sandwich. This place is a neighborhood staple for lunch. Nice sidewalk tables next to the park!!  Would be five stars but service can be a bitch sometimes.
author: Nors D.

description:
My favorite hang out in the North Beach!

A small lil joint at the butt end of NB.  The floors are wooden and busted.  The entire place is rather triangular making the restaurant a bit oddly laid out.  I enjoy places with a lot of charm and you can tell this place has a long history of it.  I mean, there has to be some story behind why a hot sandwich shop is called a Cigar Store!  

My favs are the meatball sandwich and the open faced tuna melt.   Most of the sandwiches are oven heated so the foccacia are nicely toasted with a crispy crunch to it.  Crumbs crumbs everywhere and I lick my fingertip to pick up every bit I could find on my shirt!

The must in all meals here is the coffee (bottomless btw).  I usually dump a lot of cream in my coffees, but Mario's coffee doesn't require much.  It's pure silk on it's own!  

-1 star for inconsistent service.  Some days I could be utterly ignored, and other times they'd be by your side once you pick up a menu.  Your best bet is dining at the bar area where you can just shout your order to the oven master!
author: Chris T.

description:
Love this place!  I think the best words to describe this place are: cute, quaint, friendly, & delicious.  

Mario's is on the corner of Union and Columbus right across from Washington Square.  The windows look out to the park and busy street.  It's a great spot for people watching, sipping coffee, reading a book, and catching up with a friend.  There are about 10 seats at the bar, and about 5 small tables that can fit 2 people (can fit up to 4 if you squeeze).  No big groups here!  

Very nice/helpful staff - if you have questions about the menu, feel free to ask.  You will get no rude talking back here!  As for food, there's a Great assortment of sandwiches, paninis, and salads (my friend highly recommends the meatball sandwich!)  Plus, coffees, lattes, mochas, etc.  Everything is delicious and very fresh!  I was surprised to find such a light meal here because Italian food is generally heavier, but after leaving here, I felt energized and healthy.  I will definitely be coming back!  :D
author: Naomi P.

description:
i went back on saturday around 12:30. 
it was SUPER busy and since its such a small place, it was kind of hard getting a table and service. but nonetheless, it was still delicious :) good job guys!

note: its all about timing when you come to mario's on a weekend. but its worth the wait!
author: Lisa C.

description: Good sandwiches worst service ever.
author: Ed V.

description:
I love this Place on Columbus in my favorite Neighborhood " North Beach". Small Cafe with great I mean Great Eggplant sandwiches. They are so fluffy and light and big!. They are so tasty I always get one to go. 
You can sit there with some wine or beer and people watch folks on the street or St. Mary's Park. It such a great place , check it out.
author: Susie S.

description: Mario's is more than the sum of its parts.  It's one part old wooden bar, European cafe, cozy corner hangout, and piping hot, grilled sandwicheria.  I went there last Saturday to pop in for a late night sandwich while waiting for friends, and settled in comfortably and quickly into one of the corner tables.  There was no bump or bustle, but it was still pleasantly alive.  My sandwich was near perfection, and I was disappointed I had to gobble it down so quick to meet my mates.  I could have easily spent more time lounging at Mario's over a tiramisu and coffee...
author: Laurence W.

description:
I'm no italian, but I definitely know the difference between your typical tourist trap italian restaurant on Columbus and the real deal meal-ios. These guys are definitely legit. The owner always greets my roommates and I with a smile and a ready, eager hand to cook.

This place has a neighborly feel to it more than any place I've tried in North Beach. Definitely going to recommend it. Oh, and do they actually sell cigars?? Cause I'm not seeing it!
author: Lee L.

description:
Mmmmm, almost $10 for a sandwich? Alone? With nary a side to be seen? (Well, there MIGHT have been a pickle. I don't recall, to be honest.) The frugal diner should steer clear. Also, the Frommer's-toting traveler who's not from Lilliput. My guide suggested that the BCSC's "large" sandwiches were best enjoyed across the street in the park, but I chose to stay indoors and close to the counter, lest my far-from ample meal attract the gaze and titters of passersby. That, and it was dark out. And possibly raining.

At least the ladies working the counter were a hoot.
author: Hugh R.

description:
LOVE IT ALL!! 
I've had pizza, and chicken panini's.I haven't tried their meat ball sammich but I hear its great!  My FAV is the TUNA sandwich- with melted cheese, tomatoes and a side of salad, which they are definitely generous with their portions.
The staff is AMAZING- not only is overall service a PLUS, they make you feel like family. That's what keeps me coming back to this place. My fiance and I love going to Cobb's comedy club so we always make sure to stop by and grab a bite before the show, and come back for drinks after. 

Overall it's a chill place to go on any occasion. Rain or shine, Mario's is a perfect place to go solo or with a small group of friends...
author: Sara P.

description:
We came here because of Graffeo up the  street. They recommended Mario's because this cafe serves Graffeo beans. 

We entered from the Columbus side with a  door that is slightly narrower and a door knob that is about the pop off. I get it. It's the cafe thing. Replicating something vintage, European  that sort. I like the the coziness of the cafe. Just a few small  round tables and a bar of course. Friendly staff. 

However the cappuccinos that we ordered were a bit subpar. Not the coffee but the milk foam. 

Will probably return.
author: Vince W.

description:
On my last day in SF, we were supposed to eat at Sotto Mare, but it was closed, so we found Mario's, which was said to be good.  

Mario's really looks like a small bar or cafe; there is enough seating for maybe 20 people in the bar, and it's slightly crowded in the sense of space, but that didn't bother me too much.  

When we first walked in, we weren't sure what to do because no one came to us so we seated ourselves and then requested menus at the bar.  Then we found out that there are actually servers that do that for you, and one tended to us from there.

Servers are very friendly, which was nice.  I ordered the meatball sandwich, which is HOT & delicious and possibly the most flavorful meatball sub I've eaten.  It was slices rather than a whole meatballs and covered with cheese and marinara, on foccacia bread  which was crispily toasted and served with a side of pepperoncinis.  It was an expensive sandwich ($9.75), but I would have it again.  Being the fatty I am, I had to have some of my friends' sausage sandwich, which was also really good, and a bite of my brother's canelloni, which had a homemade taste to it.  

The location of Mario's makes it a good people watching spot.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
on a crisp cold afternoon we (mostly meaning I) was starvin and looking what would crave my hunger. my boss had told me to try this out, so the bf and I headed on over. love the feel in the place; comfortable, homey, and right across the park for some good dog watching :)
we split the caesar salad- romaine fresh and crunchy, croutons were just perfect, shaved parm, and the dressing, although lightly dressed, was absolutely delicious. tasted just like our homemade version.
for the main parts- i got the meatball sandwich, him - the salami panini. i really enjoyed the marinara and the meatballs. they were fluffier, probably had a good amount of bread in them. the bread on both sandwiches were just awesomeness, asked the server and told us they get it from Bakers of Paris. his salami panini had that meaty slightly spicy thing going for it. pretty good prices too.
author: Abigail W.

description: The mozzarella panini is amazing. Takes a bit for them to prepare but, oh man, it is well worth the wait.
author: Shane R.

description:
Best Sandwich ever is "The Combo"!  If you order to go, don't let them forget the pepperoncini.  Tear 'em apart and put 'em in the sandwich!

Damn good.  

Been hooked for 20 years now!
author: Mac S.

description: ridiculous service!  the espresso was awful and asked for a refund.  the Italian sounding barman said it's a perfectly fine espresso and "you must pay 2.75" !no offer to make a different one or compromise in any way.  plain nasty experience.  after all we are on vacation Mario,  so please take it easy- your espresso is bitter,  watery and gross!
author: Michelle B.

description:
3 stars...because it's very clean, in a GREAT location, the courteous staff, and amazing foccacia bread.

However, after being told that the meatball sandwich was their "claim to fame", I was very disappointed.. while the foccacia itself was the BEST I have ever eaten (light and airy and toasted to perfection), the "meatballs" were entirely tasteless.

The unappealing, gray-colored SLICES (not "balls") of meat had absolutely no flavor whatsoever. The melted cheese and the perfectly toasted foccacia bread was excellent, but without any flavorful meat, it was a complete failure (as a sandwich).

...and sadly so..I wanted to enjoy what my server said was their best.

I will return, because of the pro's I specified above, but I won't have any high expectations about the food.
author: Ted K.

description:
I love this place. Just a tiny bar at the corner of Columbus and Union that happens to serve kickass sandwiches and Moretti in a bottle. Ended up stranded here last week when it started pouring rain and i was without umbrella. Mario's is not a bad place to be stuck inside. 

I must note that i have never purchased a cigar here, nor ever even seen a cigar here. I'm sure they are somewhere. I guess i have have a reason to go back.
author: Sean O.

description:
I was so excited to try their famous meatball sandwich and then the day my friend and I went, I had had meat lasagna the night before and the meatball sandwich just didn't sound good. So I decided to go with one of their sausage sandwiches. Overall, I think both my friend and I enjoyed our sandwiches (she got the half meatball so it was open-faced), but maybe it's just a preference, this wouldn't top my list of best sandwiches and I'm not hurrying to go back. The panini was really crispy and the sausage was good, but wouldn't be my top pick as far as flavors. I asked for some crushed red pepper and that helped.

Service was good, we went in on a weekday and they were pretty quiet. My friend wanted a diet coke but they only have specialty sodas, he brought her one to taste, but she didn't care for it, it was no problem, they didn't charge us for it. He checked in on us constantly as well.

I'd recommend anyone to try this place, it's definitely a solid sandwich, just wouldn't be the top of my list.
author: Lauren M.

description: Great sandwiches and salads.  The place is small.  The staff is friendly and fast.  Good atmosphere.  I've not had anything bad here.  Anything on their foccacia is good.  I love the eggplant, my children and husband love the meatball and chicken sandwiches.  Their coffees and expressos are outstanding.  I feel compelled to consume quickly and get out to make room for others, and there's always someone waiting for our table.
author: t d.

description: This place is one of my regular haunts.  I always recommend it to house guests visiting San Francisco.  It's good for morning coffee,  lunch, afternoon espresso, drinks, dinner.  The sandwiches are great - the meatball is the popular favorite - and the pasta is great too.  It's a good place to go with a few friends, and its great to go alone. The service is usually friendly and good, but if you go and they are in a bad mood, don't take it personally- some days are just better than others. It's a place that locals hang out, so you know its good and the prices are right.
author: Michael L.

description: One can't go wrong here. Yes, it is pricey, but look where it is. A classic place to watch the day go by.
author: S. G.

description:
it pains me to blast marios with a 1 star review because their food is good but....
Last time i ate there i ordered a chicken panini to go and while i waited for the guy to make it I watched him (with one glove on) sweep the floor, put his hand in the trash, touch multiple other dirty surface's with both hands then proceed to handle my sandwich and garnishes with unwashed hands with one glove still on. I dont mind cleaning up while you wait. but for f@cks sake wash your hands and put on clean gloves before you handle someones food. Especially if they are standing right there watching you the whole time. Based on this one experience I unfortunately will never return to this establishment.
author: kenny d.

description:
Mario's is a great neighborhood spot if you want a simple place to get affordable food and drinks and be able to talk. Doesn't sound like much to ask for, but these things are at a premium in this area. 

The location is just far enough away from all the shit hole tourist traps with neon signs down the street so there's no real spillover. Every seat is a window seat and the people watching is great with the park right across the street. 

If you're a guy over 4ft tall and have had a few Peronis, have fun trying to use the bathroom.
author: Mike S.

description: Small, friendly, doesn't feel as touristy as some of the other places on Columbus (granted, I say this as a tourist).   We only had the cappucino (very good) and the biscotti (also good).
author: Alex A.

description:
This is the spot in North Beach where my friends from Napoli like to go, bypassing all the touristy pretend-Italian joints that predominate on Columbus ave.  

For the love of god, try the meatball panini (of if you don't eat meat, the fried eggplant panini is a close second choice).  The foccacia is baked fresh daily right around the corner and it's fantastic.  Get your panini, a bottle of peroni, and watch through the window all the people walking by washington square.
author: Matthew M.

description:
I was going to say I was unimpressed with the size of the panini sandwich. But then I did some research and found out panini is the plural of panino which translates to "small bread". So egg on my face. 

So instead I'll say the panini is good and I am really anxious to try some of the bigger varieties of sandwiches. A panini is more a snack you and a friend would share as you take advantage of the beers on tap. 

But the real draw is the Americano. So far the best I have had in SF. I know it is just espresso and hot water, but beyond Starbucks it's tough to find good ones and Mario's Americano is great. 

I just love the fact you can get an espresso drink and a biscotti or other dessert or load up on carbs with beer and Italian food. Or both in the same day if you plan it right (one of these days). 

And the location right on Washington Square is unbeatable. Considering 90% of Columbus Ave is tourist traps, Mario's is a must see European style cafe, even down to the slow service. But hey, why are you in a hurry in North Beach?
author: Damen D.

description:
The bf & I were out for a long, rambling walk, & got hungry for something not-so-heavy.  Found this place via Yelp, & so glad we did!  It was about 8-8:30pm on a Sunday evening, & the place was steady, but still had several open tables.  Nice, mellow atmosphere.

We both got the meatball panini.. normally we'd try two things & share, but it sounded too good to share.  I got mine without onions, because when asked, the waitress advised that they weren't cooked (I'm not a huge fan of raw onions).  SOO yummy!  The bread was amazing!  The meatballs had wonderful fine, meaty texture & delicious flavor.  Lovely melted cheese.  And perfect serving size... enough to satisfy, but not overstuff.  And good beer.  

Cozy, warm interior.. very classic, pretty small.  Nice neighborhood-y vibe (even though it's not our neighborhood, lol).

A perfect stop for a cozy bite & sip, alone or with another.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
This is one of those joints that I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but since I'm in the area and I don't want to drive or walk super far, might as well.

Try the pastrami panini - it's a solid choice.
author: Kristine B.

description:
I have been sitting on this review for awhile, agonizing if I was going to give it 4 or 5 stars. And then it hit me: The focaccia sandwiche(s) that I have had here has become the end-all be-all sandwich to which I compare all other sandwiches.
