In the last couple of weeks, every time I eat a sandwich (which seems to be fairly frequently at the moment), I catch myself saying, "It's good, but it's not as good as Mario's." It has set the upper limit of my sandwich scale. If that's not reason enough to give this place 5 stars, I don't know what is. 

Not surprisingly, I think the secret is the bread itself - perfectly crunchy but still soft. If you want something that can only be ironically described as "health," I suggest the salami/ham sandwich. 

To. Die. For. 

The service is a little...strange. They are nice and try to be funny, but come off as just a little awkward. It's really hard for me to put my finger on it, as they are attentive and not rude, but just...different. 

Bottom line, even if the service was the most horrendous thing in the history of the world, the sandwiches would make up for it x20. Definitely a must when in Northbeach.
author: Kelsey E.

description:
three letters OMG..
this place is awesome and I mean awesome.   the fococia is just sexy and the service exceptional.  the Italian sausage sandwich is heaven.

it is my new regular spot.
author: Troy C.

description: Meatball sandwich is the bomb! Sit outside, drink a beer, eat a sandwhich, and contently watch the world go by. Great place!
author: Patrick S.

description:
This place reminds me of the cafe's they have in Europe. It's a one-stop shop for all your indulgent needs. Need a drink but also a hot meal? Done. Need a drink but can't unless you get a smoke? Done. Need espresso and a quick pastry? Done. Need all of the above? Done and done. 

I have yet to have the food here but the panini's looked amazing. The wine selection is not great so don't come here thinking you're going to get Amelie style wines (not that you would - I hope!). Next time I'll stick with beer; you can never go wrong with a Stella. 

I also want to note the generosity of the bartender who gave us a round for free towards the end of the night. Good shiz.
author: Julia N.

description:
This place is so charming and quintessential Old North Beach. The staff was very helpful, nice and easy on the eyes on this particular visit. The food is worth the walk from where I work across from SF tourist Hell (Pier 39) On this visit I had the chicken #1 on focaccia & shared a Ceasar Salad with a friend. Delicious!   
Again I have to thank Fredda H. for introducing me to this place a couple of years back. We can't figure out for the world why we don't come back here more often. This will definitely be on my top lunch time spots list.
author: Willie A.

description:
I LOVE YOUR sandwiches,  love your place, and love most of those who work behind the counter!  

THANK YOU for NOT having wi-fi because your place is so small and some motherfuckers love to hang until they die!
author: Maddy S.

description: Great sandwiches, friendly proprietors, classic North Beach charm. Ask for the Chicken #3! (Not on the menu )
author: Nate H.

description: This is the real deal....if you like to relax in 'little Italy' and dream of Florence or Lucca whilst sipping a delicious cappuccino, look no further. It is small, intimate, old-style. And very European, very Italian. I knew Mario's while growing up in NB and it's barely changed; thank god. This sweet little cafe fronts beautiful Washington Square Park and corners busy Columbus Avenue...great for people watching. Order their absolutely wonderful meatball sandwich (or any for that matter). I adore this place. All is right in the world.
author: fused g.

description: Excellent eggplant sandwich.  Also it has that "corner diner" vibe which is cozy.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Don't be fooled by the name of this place --- the focaccia sandwiches here are so yummy!!!  My favorite is the breaded eggplant.  One tiny drawback is that I think prices went up slightly and the sizes also look a bit smaller.  But I'll still come here to eat!

A great place for take-out to eat at Washington Square Park across the street on a sunny day.
author: Jean O.

description:
Best sandwich ever! 
Ever! 
Yes, it's really that good. Try their foccacia sandwiches, you'll be back again, and again for them. I go here about once a week. This place is my go to spot for chilling at a restaurant near the park, people watching, good sandwich eating, and having a great meal for a reasonable price. Don't expect the severs to wait on you hand and foot, but the service isn't bad either. They'll get your food and drinks to you in a reasonable amount of time, but since the place is so small they will probably be busy. You might have to wait to get a table if you come on a weekend, but if you're looking for an amazing sandwich, do yourself a favor and wait it out. It'll be worth it :)
author: Julie F.

description: So many good memories here. Been coming for 20 years. It' that kind of place.  North Beach might change, but Mario's does not.  The food is limited, but who cares because the sandwiches are the best you're going to get, the venue is so inviting it makes you want to sit there all day reading a paper and watching the people wander through the park.
author: cmando M.

description:
"We are going WHERE for lunch?  You are making me trek in my heels to go WHERE?  Just b/c guys don't wear heels..." is what ran through my head when a colleague/friend told me where we were going for lunch.

I would have never guessed it by the name and I'm quite sure I have passed it many times before my NB-aware friend introduced me to Mario's.  I had the warm vegetarian sandwich, which was sooo good.  To be honest, I can't recall what my friend had since I was so busy devouring mine.  The reviewers are not kidding about the focaccia.  It is really good.  The focaccia bread is fresh (none of that dry or hard business), with plenty of flavor, and the warmth of the bread embraces the ingredients that sit on top.  

Mario's decent price points make it only more desirable.  Yay!

So, why have I not gone back since that first bite?  Heels or not, I regularly remind my friend how glad I am he took me there.  A get-away from FiDi is always refreshing and for such a delicious experience -- well, I better repeat the visit!
author: Carol K.

description:
I always say that I never give out 5 stars unless I am willing to call someone and tell them about a place. This is one of those places.

I love Mario's because of it's authenticity and its history. The place has been around for many many decades and you can tell. They have amazing sandwiches (esp the chicken focaccia). They also have good selection of wines and their cappuccino's are excellent.

Above all else, it's a neighborhood spot. I love going in and sitting in the corner table and writing for hours. During the day you can people watch as they walk through North Beach or play in Washington Square park. The people who work there are all very interesting and great conversationalists. Almost as an art form. On nice weekend days, they open doors on both sides of the establishment to get a great cross breeze and an influx of neighborhood characters.

CLINCHER - They play the best music. I discovered Calexico here - one of my favorite bands

ONLY COMPLAINT - no wi-fi... then again, what restaurant/bar does right? Bad for turnover I guess
author: Peter K.

description: I LOVE LOVE this place. The focaccia sandwiches are absolutely delicious! I haven't even tried anything else. Both chicken sandwiches and eggplant are great. Staff is super friendly and chill. My boyfriend and I had a great lunch at the bar one day and our waiter asked us to find Shark Week on the TV, giving our drinks for free :) Check it out! And check out the old pictures of Mario on the wall - very historic!
author: Caitlin C.

description: This is a cool and cozy place to get something to eat and drink in a fun location with great people watching across from Washington Square park. The food is simple, but really tasty and satisfying. The meatball sandwich is great, and my personal favorite is the lasagna (which I am always a sucker for, no matter where I am). Every time I get Mario's lasagna, I am presented with a bubbling dish of gooey, cheesy, meaty, tomatoey goodness. Again, it's all pretty simple stuff, but it really hits the spot. Add to that a beer or glass of wine with a view of the (hilarious, in my opinion) segway tours that often pass by outside, and you've got it made.
author: Caroline T.

description:
I can't believe a cafe in SF doesn't have soy milk.  I had the espresso and it wasn't very impressive. My friend had a regular cappuccino and it was very clear that they don't know how to foam milk. Ironically there is not much good coffee in north beach. 

We had one of their focaccia sandwich which was good but we were certainly expecting more from a such a historical place.
author: saurabh S.

description:
I ordered a combo sandwich and an anchor steam. The guy taking my order immediately said "some guys have been coming in here and ordering that or 20 years". Good to know, I was a little concerned that I would not make it out of here alive after eating it. I am not saying this because it was bad, because it was not, it was delicious. I mean really delicious!! ...but it was all meat, cheese, and mayo on a very oily (but also delicious) focaccia roll. 

The people here were a mix of regulars and tourists. I had a good time listening to some visitors and the staff talking about the appropriate maximum amount of time to keep ground coffee beans.

They have Peroni to go along with your italian meal but if you are not into that sort of thing your only real other option is anchor steam. The rest of the beers are mostly the boring blue moon type stuff. 

Finally, Thanks for the great service. I sat at the bar and was always being taken care of. The staff obviously is intent on keeping this place the classic that it is.

I am going to try the Cannelloni next time...
author: Eric G.

description: My friend and I got the sausage sandwich and the #2 chicken sandwich: both were very good. The staff was friendly. It's a great place to sit, enjoy and watch the world go by, which is a plus.
author: Joshua C.

description:
I only had 30 minutes until my open house started so I should've ordered a salad but the hot sandwiches everyone else was eating looked way too good so I ordered a turkey sandwich with melted cheese and dijon mustard and a beer. The beer took 5 to 7 minutes and the sandwich 12 to 15 minutes even though it was not that busy. Is this too long? Not if your hanging out with friends, but it seems like forever when your eyeing the clock. The beer (Anchor Steam) was good as always, the sandwich was out of this world! Too bad I didn't get a napkin (I was served by the cook who was a little flighty, he should stick to the cooking).

If your in North Beach and want a hot sandwich and a beer and don't mind paying $20 a person with tip you owe your self a trip to this great cafe!
author: Chad S.

description:
Gavin Newsom. Here. Ordering a chicken focaccia sandwich. It was surreal.

Can you imagine his life? Wake up, cocaine, throw on fancy pants and casually sophisticated white oxford, cocaine, make a speech at whatever city event, cocaine, have lunch at Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe, cocaine, glad hand old ladies at whatever city fundraiser, cocaine, service his married cougar mistress, cocaine, act all mayorally (sic), cocaine, fall asleep in the limo. Yelp friends, it all sounds pretty GOOD to me...minus the cocaine.

Honestly, he seems like an OK guy. I would have liked to say to a few choice words to him, but I was too busy devouring my meatball sandwich. I'm fat, Gavin ain't.

Gavin Newsom, 3 stars. Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe, 5 stars.
author: John T.

description:
Love the food and atmosphere, but can't stand the arrogance of the bartenders / servers.

5+ for foccacia sandwiches

2 for staff
author: Jesse W.

description:
Despite the enticing aroma of garlic and sauces all hereabouts, I normally run screaming from any food establishment in North Beach. I've only had bland meals with fine-dining prices in this part of town, so I tend to leave Steps of Rome and their ilk to the tourists.

But Mario's has me wondering whether I've been a bit hasty.

Similar to Cafe Francisco a few blocks up, Mario's is good for a quality lunch. Also like Cafe Francisco, it's a wee bit expensive (in the $10 range), but they do have table service. I came with a co-worker, and we both had paninis, mine with chicken and avocado and the right amount of cheese. The sandwiches are on the small side, but I usually try to avoid food-coma-inducing lunches anyway.

Cozy interior, cute decor, be-Diesel-ed staff (maybe they're all actually Italian?), and a view of Washington Square Park to go with the meal ain't so bad at all.

Oh, and I don't know if they actually have cigars, but I don't think those would go well with panini.
author: Tara R.

description:
Man, that oniony foccacia bread is heavenly. I think I'd be happy if it were just a little toasted with big bowl of fruity olive oil. I've tried one of the chicken sandwiches and the meatball one and I prefer the latter. I'd say it's not a typical meatball sandwich though - it's most of a deconstructed meatball slash sausage sandwich. In any event, it's pretty good. (Sounds like the eggplant one should be next based on the other reviews...)

I like the relaxed vibe of the of place - the bartender/server guy was super friendly both times I dropped in. It's nice to know there's a mellow place to get a bite when you're too hungover to deal with anything that's remotely uncasual.
author: Alli J.

description:
4.5 stars...well I can't give 5 stars all the time or you'll never believe me.

I love this place...I'm almost a regular, but only eat lunch here about once or twice a month so that doesn't quite qualify me.

Today a Perfect Cappucino and also a perfect Eggplant Parmagiana. I only drink coffee about once a week, so that perfect gets a capital "P"  - when you only drink coffee once in awhile, it better be good. Don't ignore the parmigiana ~ it is lovely ~ delicious and hot. Other sandwiches and caprese, etc are all very good.

They should get that 5th star today for being so FAST! I've had a few lunchtimes where they slowed down my return to work too much and I couldn't come back for awhile.

Two gelaterias nearby, so you're all set for dessert. Although the cakes and pies are yummy right here.

p.s. I came here when I was very young and remember the actual cigar store! How many people can say that?!
author: Liza B.

description:
Just got back from a coffee/hot chocolate date on this beautiful, almost-sunny Sunday morning :-)!  I've lived in North Beach for almost a year and I'm sad to say that I have not been to Mario's until today.  It's a really cool cafe with great atmosphere and a great place for people watching -- straight out the window are the outstanding view of  St. Peter & Paul Church and Washington Square Park.  

The place is small, but not only do they have coffee and pastries, they  also have a good selection of salads, hot foccacia sandwiches, panini, pizza, lasagna, eggplant parm and beers (on-tap and bottle).  

Service is good... attentive, friendly and funny.  Don't ask for whipped creme on your hot chocolate because, "that's not how we roll at Mario's," according to one of the servers.  The bathroom is tiny, if you stand over 5-foot tall, I do not think you'll be able to use it.  

After finishing up our hot beverages, we were served a short-glass of sparkling h2o with lemon, which I thought was perfect. Too bad you cannot smoke cigars in here, but there are cigars available for purchase.  

I will be back again.
author: Celeste M.

description:
On a recent excursion into the city my husband and our dear friend thought it would be nice to have a cigar and a cappuccino while watching the world go by in North Beach.  

Now, all of us are from the greater Bay area, so we aren't exactly tourists from the Midwest or anything, but we aren't exactly experts on San Francisco either, so we didn't really have a clue as where to start looking for cigars, and seeing that none of us are so touristy that we read guidebooks, we had absolutely no clue that this place did not actually sell cigars anymore...oops...our bad, but this small oversight does not excuse the absolutely rancid behavior of the resident bartender....

We walked in and stood at the bar for about five minutes where we waited for the bartender to look up from the wine glass he was cleaning to acknowledge our existence.  He never does look up and give us eye contact but he finally asked us if we "needed a menu or something."

Our friend asked to see the cigar selection and the bartender snapped "we don't sell cigars and we haven't sold them for over fifteen years."

We then asked him if he would happen to know of any place nearby that does sell cigars and the bartender gets even more visibly annoyed by our mere presence and snaps, again without even looking up to acknowledge our existence "NO, I DON'T---there isn't a single cigar shop in North Beach!"

At that point we decided we didn't even want to bother with ordering a glass of water from this jerk, so we hightailed it out of there, all three of us swearing that we would never step foot in that place again.  

Now I realize that our lack of knowledge about this place did make us look like a group of idiotic tourists, but that's still no excuse for treating us like second-class citizens...and even if we had been Midwestern tourists there still isn't any excuse...I realize that tourists can be annoying and I make fun of them just as often as everyone else, but still...behavior like that is just uncalled for, no matter if someone is a tourist or not...

Anyhow, our experience was so unpleasant I doubt we will ever step foot back into this place...

And to the bartender with the slicked-back dark hair and goatee---you are a jerk and I suggest you brush up on your customer service skills.
author: Catwoman C.

description:
Before I lambaste this place I need to qualify my scathing review by admitting that I'll be back.  The only reason is that they serve Graffeo Coffee, which is easily the best stuff within a 100 mile radius.  Okay, now I can proceed to blast this place.

Let me begin by explaining that my tiff is with the waitstaff.  They have a server who is worthless and a bartender who works at a pace that rivals the speed at which grass grows.

We walked in the door on a nice Saturday afternoon and it wasn't really all that busy.  We went to the bar where we were ignored for about 5 minutes.  This server was waiting on one of the tables inside, we make eye contact, and then a table opened up outside which we promptly nabbed.  After being ignored for another 10 minutes the same server comes outside and walks past us.  I quickly asked him if he could grab us some menus as we still hadn't been served, and this guy has the nerve to suggest that I "go inside and get them at the bar" because the Sultan himself is "on a break."  Yea that guy is a complete turd burglar.  

Anyhow, I walk inside and up to the bar, I ask the bartender for the menu and she says she'll be right with me.  Another 5 minutes go by - NO EXAGGERATION.  This chic was actually moving about as fast as a glacier - and she served several other people who came after me... and all I asked for was a menu.  What the hell is wrong with these people?
author: Maxwell S.

description: Walked around North Beach yesterday morning for a half hour looking for a place that 1. was open for lunch, and 2. would fulfill my random intense craving for an eggplant parm panini and a diet soda.  Stumbled into Mario's and was happily surprised that it met these requirements.  One enjoyable conversation with the server and one absolutely delicious panini (for real... the focaccia bread was AMAZING) later, and I was happily off to enjoy the rest of my day!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Cramped, loud, piss-poor wine selection but an all-time favorite.

If you haven't had the focaccia sandwiches, you really haven't lived.

Go with a friend, get one meatball and one sausage and go "halfsies."  Otherwise if you get the meatball you're going to wish you'd gotten the sausage, and vice versa.

And don't let 'em be stingy with the pepperoncini...they'll try but don't let 'em.
author: Jay W.

description: Close to work and home I gave it a try today. Ordered a chicken panini to go. As I was waiting I saw these big, delicious, beautiful sandwiches being served so I was really excited to try mine. It didn't take very long to make and I was handed a box. When I got back to work and opened the box I was surprised to see a very small chicken panini. For $10 I thought it was going to be bigger and it didn't look like anything like what was being served. I guess what I saw was the focaccia sandwich. Aside from the size, the chicken panini was absolutely delicious!! I can say that I will return for it and maybe get a salad for a side if I'm really hungry. Service was without a smile but I noticed they are a little nicer to regulars. Taking the good with the bad, I don't doubt I will return...ya, it was that good. =)
author: Kari D.

description:
local north beach sandwich 'n' pizza bar....weekend stroll down the corner for a sluggish meal to come....one cook oven action....construction...oven bake...out..finishin' slice and plate....filled and cozy....sip on a soda, brew o' coffee....awaiting sausage..others awaiting eggplant, meatball 'n' more....wait..wait...wait...wait...waiting~~~~...patience necessary....

surprising good sandwiches.....meaty 'n' fillin'....tasting great 'n' final product actually above satisfactory.....only small questioning of sanitation of bread piled open on bookshelf corner wall....
author: Hen A.

description:
Apparently I had a cigar theme last night. Ducked in here while waiting for our table at the pizza place around the corner. Super chill vibe, and the bartender even juggled the oranges before slipping them into the blue moon.

Grabbed a nice table outside, and watched the parking on the street and everyone taking photos of the park at night. ?

I think that I just don't understand this part of town sometimes.
author: Allegra F.

description: This is a great and affordable spot to grab a sandwich in northbeach. It is one of the few places where you can find a meal for under $10 and they also have a pretty affordable wine list. Mario's is also located on the corner of Columbus right next to the park, which can be amazing for people watching.
author: Kathleen E.

description:
At first when I was told to meet for lunch at the "Cigar Store" I was a little thrown. Upon my groups hungry arrival the staff was really friendly and helped us be the (annoying people with the big group) that needed to gather more chairs. 

The Hot Foccacia Sandwiches are amazing and served really piping hot. From what I could gather they cook them right behind the bar on what seems to be a small pannini press. The ingredients were fresh and the group consensus was to come back. 

Seating: The table at the front window overlooks the streets and Jackson Park which is fun to watch. Grab it if it is free. There are also tables outside so if it is a nice day opt to sit there and watch the tourists wonder by.
author: Natalie N.

description: Foccacia sandwich!  I remember thinking, "how good could a sandwich be?"  But when I bit into it, a smile and an mmmm emerged.    Saw it on some write ups and was pleasantly surprised.  But haven't returned, not sure if I need to refresh my memory soon...
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
Great sandwich shop.  Nothing like the hot foccacia eggplant sandwich.

And to user "Catwoman" from Santa cruz - I asked you why you gave a one star review to a restaurant where you didn't even dine or order a cup of coffee.  You responded, "And why do you care what my opinion of the place is?  You live on the other side of the country and have never even been to the place I was reviewing...."   You asked me a question, and then you block me.

How do you know if I've been there or not?  You think people don't travel or live different places or move around?

I just asked you a question about your one star review where you weren't even a customer there....
author: Mercedes Q.

description:
Have been coming here every time that I visit SF since 1991. We last weekend (Jan. 10) - order the same meatball sandwich every time and love it every time. 

A few years, ago, my wife and I went, sat at the bar and someone put on a full James Brown record. Marios - meatball sandwich, great coffee and James Brown! We always talk about that experience.

Staff is very nice; food the best (at a reasonable rate) - a trip to SF is never complete until we go to Marios!
author: Allen H.

description: Get some focaccia and be happy. They also serve really good tiramisu :) Been a fan since 04. Would always go back when in north beach.
author: Adam X.

description:
Service: 2.5/5
Food: 3/5
Wait: 3/5
Price: $$
Portions: 2/5
Presentation of food: 4/5
Presentation of restaurant: 3/5
Overall: 3/5

I HAD THEIR CHICKEN PANINI WITH PESTO, ITS GREAT. BUT THE FACT THAT IM PAYING $8.50 FOR A SMALL SANDWICH... WITH NOOO SIDES WHATSOEVER, AND THEIR SALADS RANGE TO $6.50-$10! ITS QUITE PRICEY FOR SOMETHING SMALL, ITS NOT THAAAAAAT GOOD FOR IT TO BE SMALL AND EXPENSIVE. THEIR SERVICE WASN'T ALL THAT GREAT NEITHER, THEY SEEM TO DONT REALLY CARE FOR YOUR BUSINESS IF YOUR JUST THERE FOR FOOD?? IONO...
author: Eva H.

description:
When I am in North Beach (which is not often), this is the cafe that I will go to. Everyone who works there is so nice. Sweethearts. 

If you get a chance, order the cheesecake. It's not even cheesecake. It's light and fluffy and an enormous piece of heaven. The wife of the owner couple makes this at home. Mm. I am thinking of heading over there later today just to get me some of that.

And... their sandwiches are amazing - no fuss, simple is better, high quality ingredients. The perfect place to spend a lazy few hours.
author: Annie T.

description: Yay Meatball! Cheap Italian style food in North Beach? Yes! It exists! Mario's is a great place to get an affordable tasty meal, have a drink, and oogle all the people as they pass by Columbus Ave. I highly recommend the Meatball Sandwich. I think it's the only thing worth ordering. mmm. Pilsner and Meatball.
author: Netty L.

description: Omg yum! We stopped in for sandwiches late in the afternoon and were not let down. We got the grilled eggplant and the chicken number 1 and were very pleased with our meals. Personally, I had the eggplant and it was so delicious!  The foccacia was very flavor and crispy and the filling was just right. Highly recommend!
author: Lisa C.

description:
Tasty Barolo / 
Religous Focaccia / 
Cute Peeps, no cigars.
author: Baer T.

description:
Mario's is bella bella. Wonderful atmosphere to sit and sip brews with friends. The decor is vintage, and I hate to say it but it sort of feels like a "Central Perk" type neighborhood place. I love it. 
The paninis? Oh heaven! Just make sure you're not too drunk to enjoy it, and make a note to let it cool down. I burned my mouth numerous times because I was too impatient to wait till the melty-hot, obscenely delicious creation cooled down.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Best. Lasagna. EVER. 

Bohemian, yes... Cigars, not so much. Which is great news, because instead they have delicious food!

I personally ordered the grilled eggplant panini, which was incredible, but the lasagna was actually the best of its kind that I've tried yet. The carafe of red wine and the sunny day certainly helped, although it did get a touch cold on the terrace because the sun wasn't directly hitting it. Despite the homeless serenader and the nippiness, however, it was a fabulous way to spend a lovely President's Day and be outside after such a long week of rain. Our server slash bartender was friendly, in a quirky hipster kind of way, and the prices were the usual North Beach standard... which, in this case, were absolutely worth it. Very quaint, right next to Washington Square Park, and great for people-watching without being right slap in the middle of the chaos. Even the bizarre restroom set-up seemed strangely enchanting after such a scrumptious meal and charming experience!
author: G. J.

description:
I've eaten here a few times and I've always had a great experience. The restaurant has a great location, open and close to plenty of shopping, historical landmarks and a beautiful park.

The sandwiches are absolutely delicious and well priced and the service is always great (although sometimes a little slow). The only negative I have to say about this place is that the seating is limited and a little cramped, it can be hard to find a table, or sometimes even move around.
author: Matthew S.

description: North Beach is full of false havens but this place is legit- a pearl. The grilled foccacia sandos are unreal in their deliciousness. I can't say I have had it done better EVER. The lasagna is very good as well. The space is utterly classic and brimming with character without being kitschy or... well... dirty. It's a great place for a casual evening dinner that really knocks it out of the park with how tasty everything is. I also believe the owner does all the service so he is of course very attentive and wants to keep you happy which he does with ease. This will now be my go-to place to eat in North Beach.
author: Matt L.

description: Nice corner bar. The manager/bartender was arrogant and ignored me for awhile. Didn't want me taking pictures. It would be great if the service was just a little friendlier.
author: Donald A.

description: Very cool place, never changes. Quintessential old North Beach. Fried eggplant sandwiches and drinks are great!
author: Stephen N.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed this place!  Mario's is an institution in a neighborhood full of institutions.  The place just oozes character in its funky little way.  The sandwiches are great, the beer is cold, the location is rocking.  One of those places that so easily could have been taken over by tourists and stripped of its character (there are plenty of tourists, but the character is still intact), Mario's still is going strong.  
Go with a friend or two, get a carafe of the house wine, and just enjoy.
author: Blake W.

description:
OOOOH MY GOOOOOD
Yeah baby....
MMMMMM MMMMM

This is the place to go for a huge meatball sandwich and a slice of tiramisu

the meatball sandwich comes with flavorful tender meatballs in a rich mild tomato sauce and mozzarella cheese enclosed within two fresh slices of foccacia bread. This sandwich was huge and definitely you will have leftovers.

Have a slice of their tiramisu. Creamy, fresh, lightly sweet and delicious.
author: Charlene C.

description:
History in the  making, one of the oldest cafes in North Beach. 

Unpretentious cafe feel, so you feel welcome right away. Grab a seat at the bar, a table by the window or if it's sunny you may be lucky enough to get a spot outside. 

Great vibe, local hangout spot, friendly bar staff. 

Great panini sandwiches served on foccaccia bread. I had the tomato mozzarella panini and loved it. 

The servers move as fast as they can, but don't expect miracles as this place can get pretty busy. 

Portions are a little smaller than I would've expected. 

I give 3 stars because I was in a rush and the bar server was taking his sweet time as if I didn't have to rush back to the Fidi.
author: Cellina B.

description:
I used to live around the corner from Mario's and it was one of my favorite North Beach spots.  The polenta & sausage dish was my fave but I don't think I ever ate anything I didn't like there.  The hipster waiters are a little stand-offish but they warm up once they get to know you.  The dreadlocked dude (does he still work there?) didn't really acknowledge my existence until I had been a regular for about a year.  But I figured he was the guy picking all the great reggae music so I lived with it.

They also have some seats outdoors across from the park which are a great spot for and afternoon lunch.
author: Luke F.

description:
Mario's is a great place to hang out on a rainy afternoon or evening. It's a neighborhood spot - tourists tend to stay out. 

I simply haven't found a better meatball sandwich, ever. The other items on the menu are good. The pizzas are nice. But I only eat the meatball sandwich.
author: Mark M.

description: I instantly loved the neighborhood vibe I got from this place. A small joint, nothing fancy but not grimy either. My friend and I went family-style and ordered the mozzarella panini, eggplant parmesan,  a basket of focaccia bread, and pinot grigio. I have no complaints. The food was impeccable. Overall, if you are looking to have a quick bite (not fast food) in an unpretentious environment, check of this North Beach classic.
author: Joan S.

description:
cozy, functional, unpretentious, well-priced, good service.  We went during the north beach fest, and these guys were even keeled about it, when they could have been up-itty and annoyed.  Peroni on draft.  Panini's looked great, i'll be coming back for lunch on a regular basis.
Bathroom sucked, whats new, its north beach.
author: Christian W.

description:
I've been going here with my dad and my grandmom since I can remember. Every friend I've brought here has been impressed and wanting to come back! We only go here for the focaccia sandwiches. I've had all of the sandwiches on the menu, and my faves are probably the meatball and the chicken dijon.  I dont know how they do it, but the bread is just perfect. every. time. Crispy and oniony on the outside, with the perfect soft bread on the inside.
 I've also had one of their salads before...I forget what it was called but there's slices of mozerella cheese and tomatoes, with spinach leaves, topped with pesto sauce. that was also pretty delicious. 
I cannot get enough of this place. its a really cute, local little cafe at the corner across from Washington Square park. a great place to people watch!

Just to add a story to this post, I went in there with some friends one day, and this Italian guy was at the bar. he comes up to our table, pulls up a chair, and says to me "you look just like my ex girlfriend back home!" and we start up a conversation. It was fun, he was nice. A cool place to meet people too. haha.

Also a good thing: they open until 11pm!!!
author: Mary K.

description:
So, today for lunch my boyfriend and I were looking for a place, and as we tried to go to Mama's (yet again, but an absurd line), we almost went to our usual standby Cafe Divine, but we decide to go to this place instead.

We walked in and sat down, and the first thing I noticed was the cool place.  I was just digging sitting there.  I think it would be a great place to go and just have some coffee or a beer or something and hang out. 

We sat by the window and had a great view of the park.  We browsed the menu and I decided on the meatball focaccia sandwich, and he wanted the sausage sandwich.  Mostly so we could just share and each try half of a sandwich.  I had some coffee and we just sat there and enjoyed the atmosphere, the music, and the view.

The food came, and it was pretty darn good.  I think the meatball sandwich was better than the sausage sandwich, but I was happy with both of them.  The focaccia is great too, I don't think they make it there, but it was tasty!  

I'd definitely go back for lunch sometime.  There were several other sandwiches on the menu I wanted to try, and the coffee wasn't bad either!  More than anything, I just loved the atmosphere, the view, the company, and the food!  I guess that's everything there!
author: Grant T.

description: The best Meatball sandwich I've ever had. I love this place, I always stop in when I'm in Northbeach. Great Italian beers - great atmosphere, get there early because it gets crowded. Hit it on a weekday.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
OK, folks. I get the charm of this cafe's location and setup. Sipping a coffee or glass of wine in the corner or outside at a table on a warm afternoon (today was unusually warm) is a great way to spend time. But I bellied up to the bar for one of the panini's and walked away (far too many minutes later) having eaten half of what must be described as the least flavorful sandwich I've ever spent good money on in this town. 

The big, sloppy, hot foccacia sandwiches ordered by others looked more appealing and I understand this might be about my choices, but come on! My "panini" came on a grocery store roll that was filled with mediocre lunch meat, almost no blue cheese (it was a smoked turkey/blue cheese sandwich) and a few red onions. The only  distinguishable flavor was the burnt bottom. I'm OK with dark grilling ... a little scorch can make the sandwich. But it was the ONLY flavor stand-out.

Service was friendly enough and they treated the regulars very well. My server saw the disappointment on my face and charged me for what I ate - half a sandwich. I'm not afraid of eating a lot at lunch and I was looking forward to a full belly, but I won't finish something I'm not enjoying. 

With all this neighborhood has to offer, why would anyone spend a dime on a sandwich that doesn't meet even the most modest expectations of flavor?

One star for a perceptive server.
author: Steve J.

description: Went only cuz Molinari's was closed.   :( Pretty good sandwiches. Waited 30+ min for take out.
author: J P.

description: Used to be great. The service is awful. I wish the owner would hire more competent people.
author: Angelo A.

description: Classic North Beach! Mario's has been here for decades. The service is polite and friendly. The food is basic and oh so delicious! No fancy frills needed. Great view out into Washing Square Park; sit inside or outside. The name is slightly deceiving as they don't sell cigars anymore, but this place is pure history. Love it!
author: Bae L.

description:
Lovely little cafe overlooking Washington Square. From the comfort of your seat, while sipping delectable hot chocolate, you can see the bronzed yoga man in nothing but shorts on a cold day, dog walkers pretending not to notice when their dog takes a shit, and random children playing (not sure I knew children actually existed in this city)

Good food, interesting people watching, and a nice respite from the usually touristy North Beach.

Note: Not actually a cigar store. Don't go in here thinking you'll pick up some Cubans on the down low. Not gonna happen.
author: Ali L.

description:
Gah. I hate to do this. I really do. I wanted to like you Mario, but you just weren't for me.
Maybe it was the rainy dreary weather.
The hunger.
The thoughts that kept drifting to Liguria's or Mama's or even Tartine's in the Mission...
Whatever it was, this didn't match up. 
I was determined to try a new place in North Beach since I had been to a couple of the places already.
Liguria's- good.
That other place on the corner that was pretty un-rememberable that I don't remember the name- not that special.
But, I was yelping and I had just dropped off stuff in Chinatown to get altered, so I thought I would try the paninis here.
In truth, they were okay. The bread was okay and the toppings okay.  A pretty good "half sandwich" for 5.50. Turkey for my mom, veggie for me. But bland sir, bland for my taste. I was hoping for some interesting spread or quirky cheese to spice it up, but it was just...okay. I had this eggplant affixation, but alas this place did not relieve me. 
However, on the upside, probably one of the best mochas I've had. So go there for the drinks. Or at least the mocha.
author: jeddie k.

description: Very cute Italian style coffee shop we stopped at to recharge.  They have a full selection of coffee drinks and beers as well as a great staff.  I wish I can give bonus points because they had a phone charger that they let me use.
author: Yan P.

description:
Sunny: I had their salami panini on a baguette. Absolutely fantastic: hot, crispy and flavorful. Simple ingredients, but the combination, with the panini press and voila! I would love to visit this place again. The atmosphere and friendly staff are great. 

Nolan: Mario's is one of my favorite hang outs in north beach, it is a great place to be a regular at.  Their panini's are and focaccia sandwiches are delicious, great to enjoy on a nice day in the park or on a colder day in the restaurant with a pint.  My favorites are the salami panini, and grilled chicken #1 and #2 focaccia sandwiches.  They do a great home made tiramisu too!
author: SunnyandNolan E.

description:
We popped in here to have a beer whilst we decided what to do for dinner.  It has a really friendly atmosphere, even though the Reggae music was a little loud and not really to my taste.

At the far end of the bar we could see a chap making and stretching the dough for pizzas and cooking them in a small pizza oven.  They smelled pretty good and we were having fun so decided to stay for one.  We had the Italian Meat pizza which was ok.

The owner (or at least the bar man) was very kind and attentive, when my other half was coughing he noticed and brought over a glass of water and after we'd settled up he came over and gave us a half of beer each on the house.  Nice touches that reinforced initial impressions.

Be warned that if you're particular about your Rest Rooms this place only has 1 for everyone and the door is a little rickety, and the basin is in the hallway - but that's kinda in keeping with the relaxed feel of this place.
author: David W.

description:
BEST CAPPUCCINO IN SF!!!
Im serious. And the food is great too. I beeline here whenever Im in the 'hood.
author: Mollie M.

description:
Been eating here since the days of them selling cigars. Yeah it stunk up the plaace, but now we can reminisce how cool it was...
     Look most places in North Beach are touristy traps, but the  places still original in my book are Marios and Stellas down the street. They treat you right here, are nice and by the way make good foccacia sandwiches. Hits the spot after a walk from the Embarcadero over the Filbert Steps.
     They play pretty good catch with the dishes when they're done cleaning them too! Never seen em drop one!
author: Perry M.

description: Excellent place, with a lot of character.  Feels like one of these old café-bars from Southern Europe.  Both coffee and desert were excellent.  The place is cozy or crammy, depending on your perspective.  Servers are on the slow side, but extremely polite.
author: A R.

description:
GABRIEL
Jer, you have the check out the meatball foccacia.
JERRY
The fu*k gotcha?  What is that?
GABRIEL
Foccacia.  Sandwich bread.
JERRY
Fu** atcha?
GABRIEL
The meatball sandwich.  It's good.  Bread's thick.  Meat's good.  And they  have two of those spicy things on the side.
Jerry looks over and sees a meatball foccacia (my recommendation).
JERRY
Just how I like my women: crispy on the outside.  meaty on the inside.  spicy on the side.
GABRIEL
You used that line in another review, dude.
author: T. F.

description:
Note: no cigars or related found here. Sorry, cigar aficionados. 

Ambiance:
Small and cozy, about 4-5 tables for three, with a bar. Quaint dark wood interior, and a split door entrance with character. Everyone is guaranteed a view of lovely green Washington Square, which is directly across the street. Depending on who is manning the CD carousel, you'll be listening to soothing bossa nova, new age world music, or lively Spanish salsa. Loud but not too loud for table conversation.

Seems to be a quiet choice for active, 20s and 30s North Beach locals who happen to be in the vicinity. Not one tourist to be seen.

Only one bathroom. It's in the back, as large as an airplane restroom, without the mirror. Seems almost like it was installed as an afterthought.

Drink: 
Kinda on the small portion size for the money, but hey, it's North Beach. Tea options are nothing exotic and quite limited (about 5 choices of bagged supermarket-grade tea), while coffees are standard fare. They do better by their coffee. Of course, they also have beers, many in bottles and about 3 on tap - I'm personally happy to find Italian beers here, even if only in bottles.

Food: 
The desserts are a bit disappointing. Their tiramisu and ricotta cheesecake are the only ones homemade there. The cheesecake tasted nothing of cheese, strongly resembling angel food cake in taste, look and texture. The lower half of the cheesecake was some sort of egg custard. Better to go with a meal order, as that is where their strength lies.

Service: 
Good and friendly. The staff is youthful, calm, all smiles and happy to give recommendations and answers.
author: Clar L.

description:
This is a great place to eat lunch or take it out and eat it in Washington Square Park (on one of the few days San Francisco is nice to you and the sun shines). 

I will order anything with the dijon mustard on it and Chicken #1 and the meatball sandwiches are my favorites! It takes awhile for them to make your sandwich (about 10 minutes if they're not that busy), but it's worth the wait. The foccacia bread they put the sandwich on is so good.

The cheesecake was kind of a disappointment though. It kind of tasted like thick egg bread and wasn't what I expected at all.
author: Esther K.

description: This place is fun...low key little neighborhood place that my sister recommended. We had yummy pizza. A fun little find.
author: Deborah S.

description:
You know those random Sundays when you can't motivate yourself to work out or run errands?  When all you want to do is relax and be entertained on the cheap...anywhere other than your apartment?  Well, Mario's is my solution for those particular doldrums.

Come in with yourself and either a book or a friend.  Order a coffee or a glass of wine, and perch at the bar or grab a tiny table next to the window.  Sit as long as you like and watch the tourists, church-goers, and older Tai-Chi-loving folks in Washington Square Park.  

Breathe, grab a little snack, and relish that you have a whole afternoon before you have to get back to grindstone on Monday.
author: Deidre B.

description: Great little cafe with excellent food and good service! My girlfriend and I visited San Francisco and went to this place almost every day! Every time we tried somewhere else, it wasn't as good and we thought, "Why didnt we just go to Mario's?"
author: Sherman M.

description:
On a whim, or rather, on a bit of Yelp research, I discovered Mario's.  
Yelp again succeeds- the eggplant foccacia sandwich not only made me solidify my position on eggplant in the positive. I found myself searching the plate for any dropped crumbs of this sandwich that I could find after devouring it. 

It's a bit pricey for sandwiches, but not too pricey for awesome sandwiches.
author: Dan W.

description: Chicken foccacia sandwiches. There are two on the menu and they're both delicious. Get one of those and an Anchor Steam beer. Pick up a Chronicle from the corner (the crossword puzzle will be done but that's ok). Grab a table by the window overlooking Washington Square park. Get another Anchor Steam. You, my friend, are having the best lunch in the City.
author: Brian B.

description:
I got my karmic payback for making light of herpes the other day.


 You see, shortly after making fun of the social disease, I sprouted a pimple on the inside of my lip, and anyone who's ever had any sort of blemish or bump or whatever inside their mouth knows that they can hurt like a bitch!


 So it was without thinking of this ailment that I bit into a pepperocini while at Mario's. OH GOD DAMMIT TO HELL THAT BURNS! I shoved the generous portion of the offending pickled peppers to the side of my plate.


 I took a bite of my heapingly huge foccacia sandwich (your choice of fillings: chicken, eggplant, sausage, you name it!) as the crusty corner of the deliciously perfect foccacia brushed against my lip-pimple. OWW! OH GOD, OK, I WON'T MAKE JOKES ABOUT PEOPLE'S LIP & COOCHIE SORES ANYMORE. AND I WON'T USE YOUR NAME IN VAIN. PLEASE, JUST MAKE IT STOP.


 But it was so good, I continued to eat.


 Thank you, Mario, for serving up delicious food, a very cozy and homey atmosphere, and lessons in karmic retribution and humility before god.


 Note to those confused by the name of the business: The food is not Bohemian in any way, and while cigars are sold, they cannot be smoked here. If anything, it's more of a casual Italian restaurant and wine bar with a dark, homey atmosphere that could've once been a den of cigar-smoking and backroom deal-making.
author: Omid T.

description:
I can't believe that I just realized that I hadn't drafted a review for Mario's!!!!  It must be all the drinking that I've been doing!!!  Some of which was actually done at Mario's.  This little joint is FULL of San Francisco character.  

Are you from out of town and want a slice of North Beach?   Visit Mario's!  They have a slim alcohol list (beer and wine), but the food...oh the food...and the atmosphere.  There is a cast of regulars, as well as tourists that happen to stumble upon this little gem.  Oh...two words...focaccia...and panini...

Now talk amongst yerselves, dahlings!
author: Hiromi N.

description:
No smoking of cigars, but the oven baking the focaccia sandwiches can fill up the place with that burnt bread smell that's actually kind of nice, but makes your clothes stink for days.  I've enjoyed every visit to Mario's.  It's the kind of place that I would love to own.  Or what I'd use as a template for the perfect comfortable cafe with food and wine.  I order a half carafe of the montepulciano, an Italian red and the eggplant marinara sandwich on focaccia.  They layer the sandwich with thin slices of breadcrumb coated fried eggplant, roasted red peppers and then a layer of provolone.  Then bake it open-faced in the oven on the wall.  After ten or fifteen minutes, they slap the two sides together and slice it diagonally and garnish with those green pepperocinis, which I bite the end off, pour the tangy vinegar into the sandwich and then munch down as I eat the sandwich and sip the red wine in smallish hexagonal tumbler glasses.  
One memorable time was when my brother Rufus visited and we went there on a Monday for dinner.  It was raining out.  We ate and had the wine.  It continued to rain, they had cool music playing.  Coltrane or Sonny Rollins or Thelonious Monk...  Anyway, we didn't leave that place for 3 hours just laughing about dumb things we used to do as kids and can now talk about.  No reason to go out in the rain when you've already found a cool place to hang.
I do have to admit that in the past few years, the charm has changed a bit for the worse.  The lighting is now much brighter and too bright in my opinion. I like it dim when work on getting a good wine buzz.  And the jazz music has been replaced by either dancey world music or reggae or just contemporary Alice-type music.  Maybe it's the workers who just play their iPods or whatever they want.  
The great foccacia they use for the sandwich is from Liguria Bakery on the corner of Stockton and Filbert, but the Italian French Bakery up the street on Grant @ Union makes a decent substitute, but it's not the soft wonderful foccacia from Liguria.  There's a difference.  They ran out of the Liguria foccacia bread for the sandwiches a couple of times too and I asked about when they changed to the Italian French Bakery foccacia, our waitress was convinced it's always been the same.  They also installed a few taps of draft beer, which is nice, but I suggest the red wine with the sandwiches.  2006, the old school is changing.

Update:
They had a sign on the window saying they're using Liguria focaccia.  Hmm.  Maybe they read the yelp reviews...cool.
author: Kev M.

description:
"The best sandwich I have EVER had." You must go to Mario's and have the Chicken #2. Sit outside and drink some wine-- just be sure you get the one table with sunshine.

UPDATE!!!!!

So I have been to Mario's twice since this review and the Chicken #2 was lame... Still love the ambiance. Looks like I am going to have to order something new next time.
author: C J.

description:
Cheaper and more reliable than the string of overpriced tourist-centered Italian cafes down the block. This place is cozy without the overly-friendly waiters that I find to be overbearing in most of North Beach. 

Good lunch spot for panini, focaccia sandwiches (breaded eggplant!), cannelloni and lasagna. Go at off-times (like 2pm for lunch) since table seating is sparse and this place tends to fill up.
author: Mindy S.

description: Just love the entire scene of this place. Its at the corner of Washington Square Park. They have outdoor seating, and a cozy indoor cafe/bar. The sandwiches are so good on their fresh Foccacia bread, definitely get the Meatball. They also have pitchers of beer to wash it all down. Just a really great find in my favorite neighborhood!
author: Sean C.

description: Got the meatball sandwich and a coke for $14.  This isnt a traditional meatball sandwich, i.e. sandwich roll with three whole meatballs covered  in sauce and cheese.  Rather, it uses a thin, but delicious focaccia bread, which was excellent.  It's not as saucy as your normal sub; the sauce, meatballs (chopped in 1/2)  and the cheese were all well proportioned.  Service was fine.  Ambiance was fine.  If you want a great meatball sandwich, try it out.
author: brett k.

description: Amazing meatball sandwich, out of this world tiramisu, perfect coffee, and one completely hip and comfortable place!! Especially since all can be had for next to nothing!
author: David B.

description:
Stumbled upon this place at about 2 on a Monday afternoon while looking for a quick and yummy bite after visiting Alcatraz and climbing way up to Coit Tower. It was the perfect spot to plop down and kick back and relax for a few and, upon walking in, you could tell it was a neighborhood classic.

The staff was super-friendly. When my girlfriend inquired about their Sabu Bloody Mary they told her it wasn't very good - honesty is the best policy, right? Instead, we ordered a couple Anchor Steams and waited for our food. The bathroom was unique but clean and funny to use.

I ordered the smoked turkey hot focaccia sandwich which was perfectly grilled and delicious. It was served with a great cucumber salad and pickle. My girlfriend ordered the eggplant pizza which was delicious as well (although the crust seemed oddly similar to frozen pizza crust).

Prices were fairly good, although on the high end but the personality the place has totally made up for it. Overall, loved it!!
author: Adam B.

description:
I'm a meat guy- so for a portabello mushroom sandwich to knock me over and kick my ass several times as I pleaded for more is a giant leap of vegetarian faith...and that's exactly what happened:  me, first bite- whoa- I fall over on the floor and let  the pummeling begin.

The foccacia bread alone- I could just have a bread sandwich, I believe they get it from that mom n pop shop just down the road.  Anyway- I'm headed down to SF this weekend and I look forward to another beating.
author: Knathan R.

description: Great spot for people watching & having a beverage. Liked the staff - was offered a free beer, but seeing as I don't drink beer anymore and my date was doing all the driving, we declined. Food looked good.
author: Corinne L.

description: Perfect SF hang out.  Best turkey sandwich I've ever had.
author: Mike W.

description: This place is the perfect little hole in the wall. It always has a crowd, but never the overly busy feel to it. It is a very cozy corner shop with friendly staff, beautiful focaccia bread and a diverse crowd of tourists, regulars and passersby.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
IT IS WORTH THE CALORIES!
My favorite thing about work--Is the lunch hour.  No seriously, I brake for lunch only because the food is so good in North Beach, not because I need the pounds.  Can I tell you--Mario's is my office away from the office. We go there daily for meetings and you will not find better canneloni, well, pannini's well, lasagna and bread and hefty pours of wine.  All in all, it is the neighborhood hang out and we Love It.  The people that work there are not servers they are friends.  This place rocks.  Not Low Cal but Worth It!
author: Elisa B.

description:
I have been eating at Mario's for years.  As big, and I mean BIG a pain as it can be to find parking in the area, it is well worth the effort.  Cozy up the to bar and have a beer while perusing the simple but well done menu.  I love the combination focaccia sandwich.  They buy the focaccia fresh every morning from a focaccia bakery right across Washington Square.  I have heard the vegetarian sandwich is really good too.

It is a family owned business and they treat customers really well.  I know of a couple of generations of families who frequent Mario's.  Suck it up and deal with the parking.  It will be worth it.
author: David S.

description:
I used to always get my lunch here. I miss your sandwiches. That's all I've ever ordered here, and I miss them dearly. Perfect in a lot of ways, minus one. It's no longer close to home.

Miss the great service, and humble atmosphere.
author: Charles K.

description:
A charming little spot in North Beach to take a friend for a casual bite or to read a book and have a glass of wine alone.
I work next door to Mario's so i've never had the pleasure of actually dining there but I do take-out on average once a week and i'm always envious of the people chillin in this cozy hang out.
I usually order the eggplant parmesan which is made with a flavorful marinara and plenty of good cheese.  The pizza is also delicious, italian style with a cracker crust.  A filling meal or a light snack for 2.  For the quality the price can't be beat.  The wine list could use a little work but that wouldn't stop me from coming back again and again.
author: Kaylee T.

description: Oh for the love of sandwiches and everything that is holy in this world!  I went here on a blind date the other night.  While the guy was less than mediocre, the warm eggplant sandwich and baby green salad was amazing.  More please!!!   I generally shy away from eggplant but I am SO happy I chose to go for it this time.  It was perfectly prepared, SO tender and perfectly seasoned.  I don't know what they put on that sandwich but I can tell you it was a mouth full of love and deliciousness.  YUM.  The waitress was great too- actually she had more personality than my date =)  Well worth the time!  I say gitcher butt in there and order the sammich ASAP
author: Moto L.

description: Driving around the city looking for a place open at 3pm for food! HUNGRY!! Ended up walking around Northbeach and walked right into this place seeing that it was crowded, must be good right? The staff was very nice, young guys hype and charming, mocha came out mmm it was good but could be a tad hotter. Ordered the meatball hot sandwich and caprese salad. The pesto on the Caprese salad was to die for! Soaked up every last drop with extra bread! The sammys took an hour to come out! YES an HOUR! man lucky the staff was real nice or I would of bitten their arms off I was so hungry! The sammy was yummy. Goey cheese, good meatballs and delicious focacia bread with green onions Oh my ! I would go back just for that focacia. I had a quarter of my friend's eggplant sammy and it was just OK, it was too salty for me. I love eggplant sammys, I've had better. It was good, if I lived in the hood I would be there alot. Since I'm not at NB too often I don't know when I'll be back.
author: Karen T.

description: A meatball sandwich like you've never had.  Simply da best!
author: Robyn C.

description:
Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store Cafe is a great place to the following...

- Get lit at the bar and make small talk with people.

- People watching on the outside tables.

- Drinking coffee and/or eating very good focaccia bread inside on a nice day.

Great place to bring a party of 2 or more.
author: Buddy R.

description:
Stellar cafe, and a true San Francisco landmark.  Most of the Italian joints in North Beach are cheesy, but this one has the history and food to match the great location (right on Washington Square).

Pull up a chair at the counter, order your machiatto (they make them well) and get a grilled sandwich.  Best sandwiches in North Beach, only caveat is don't sit outside cuz sometimes the staff will forget about you.
author: Aaron K.

description:
Yummy

Corner of Union and Columbus, right next to the park.

Good coffee

Good meatball sandwich

Good atmosphere

great way to start a day
author: Kevin C.

description:
I can't really be objective about Marios. I've  been going to Marios for so long -- I've known so many people who work(ed) there spanning so many eras. It's a true North Beach institution and rivals Cafe Trieste and some others in that regard. It has its 'people' and following. I can't be objective about the food or service, since I've had everything they make 1000 times and know everyone personally who works there. This place has been a home to me. And I appreciate Paulo the owner and all the various people over all the various time periods that has made Marios a part of my life.

For the unintiated, Marios is a place you go to just hang out and be merry. You have some red wine, order a pizza or a meatball sammy and talk loud and be animated or sit outside on the stockton street side between 4-6 when the sun is shining there and people watch.

Be cool with the people who work there and they will be cool with you. Tip well and they will be even cooler.

Marios hours sort of roll with how busy it is, it can be open late. In the old days it was open really late on weekends, and I still think the owner should re-consider serving food til 12:30am on Fri and Sat., as there is nothing this end of the 'hood to get a pizza when hungry late.

They selection of food is not vast, but it what it is and its consistent. This is not a place to come in being a vegan or foodie. Just be cool. Bring a cool book or some post-cards or a scrabble board or deck of cards or your flyers for your next gig or some Euro hotties you just met -- converse, hang out, see what happens -- and enjoy a beer and go on about your business. A pretty good tiramisu, carrot cake and some other treats to go with the coffee. No soy here! You want raw milk without pasteurization? I applaud you -- just don't come looking for that at Marios. This is a good old fashion real authentic north beach haunt.

Bravo!


PS
Once you couldn't smoke inside anymore, they did away with the cigars -- and they finally got a credit card machine a few years back after being known for "cash only" -- i took great pleasure watching a guy on a first date sadly have to make the walk up the block to the ATM...ah, the good ole days... :-)
author: R A.

description:
Ages ago a friend took me there and recommended the eggplant parmesan focaccia sandwich. It was so good that I've never been able to order anything else. About once a week (or more) I get this undeniable craving and HAVE to go. It's wonderful. 

In addition I like the environment. It's never too crowded, the people working there are really mellow and friendly and it's got this nice patina of age. If their sandwich wasn't sublime, I'd probably still go there sometimes for a drink. But I'm glad that their sandwich exists.
author: Sonia H.

description:
Food was okay for the most part. Salads were sad but the meatball sandwhich was great.

Service was awful. Our waiter was incredibly rude, sarcastic and arrogant. That, along with the long wait for the food and the bill, made the whole experience a nightmare.

After we finished the meal and asked for the bill we waited over a half an hour and eventually had to ask the waitress to remind our waiter because no one in our group even wanted to talk to him at that point. 

As good as that sandwhich was the service was so bad there is no way i would ever go back.
author: K B.

description: I've lived in S.F. for over 20yrs and would come here at least once a month. I moved away but still have to stop by here every time I visit my family to get my meatball sando fix. Bar None the best meatball Sandwich ever. I sit at the bar, order an Anchor Steam and feel like I never left. The staff is great, they remember me and address me by name, which is amazing.
author: Ebert S.

description: Really delicious sandwiches. I've had the meatball and the eggplant sandwiches on focaccia and they were both really good. This is a nice, low key neighborhood spot where it's usually easy to get a table.
author: Amy K.

description:
This has been my favorite hangout in the world since my first visit in 1973, the year the Crismani family took over the former "Bohemian Cigar Store" (which really did sell cigars), and i arrived in NB. it had been one of the several "Italian old men" coffee/wine bars in North Beach. they were all gone by the late '70's, the Portofino (where Cafe Roma is today) and others i can't remember the names. within months Mario kicked out all the old guys, took out their old Italian pinball machines, and completely shifted the customership to all us 20-somethings who were flooding into San Francisco and NB in the 70's, plus its many continuing beat-era denizens. very smart business plan, betting on the future. there were no windows on the Union Street side at all, those were added in the 80's. Mario kept a box of cigars under the counter to sell just in case someone wandered in and asked for one until he passed away in the 90's. at some point around then they had to take out the Foosball game in the back to add more tables because the landlord raised the rent a lot, also adding the sidewalk tables outside. but aside from such details it really hasn't changed at all. they have had the good sense not to redecorate or try to update. it still has one of the funkiest (but clean) bathrooms in town. Lilliana still bakes the pastries, the sandwhiches are tasty, and the servers are always very neighborhood-y. the generations of customers, servers, and passers-by shift with the years, but the place is timeless.

just thought i'd offer some history for context.
author: John E.

description:
This is one hell of a little fantastic place to grab a drink and a quick gnosh. The sandwiches and pizza are pretty effin great.

I even saw the bartender carefully take down a poster from the wall and give it to a customer because the customer liked it. 

Deliciously San Franciscan. Don't miss out.
author: David F.

description:
The place is cool to hang out, have good coffee, or a beer.  I ordered a chicken panini sandwich that was insipid, I asked for some olive oil and vinegar to dip my sandwich into because I couldn't taste much flavor but the bread was good.

The server was nice, I sat on the bar by the door which was kind of annoying since people kept walking in without closing the door and it was windy.  Really people, you walk into a place, close the door behind you, is called courtesy.  Try it.
author: Silvia T.

description:
I didn't notice any cigar business going on here

I had a great experience here on a beautiful summer July evening.  
Mario's is small, but has plenty of San Francisco charm that you'd expect in North Beach.  There's a nice mix of international and local folks that come here. Since I'm a music snob I noticed they had some reggae on the ipod which helped the laid back vibe. Hence the Bohemian in "Mario's Bohemian Cigar Store.

I ordered a Salomi, Jack cheese Panini and the GF grabbed the chicken pesto with sun dried tomatoes.  The sandwich is a decent size, and very tasty.  Great place for a glass of wine and some food.

FYI Take your parents here for lunch when they visit.  They'll love the Neighborhood
author: Robert M.

description: This is a great spot to grab a pannini for supper and a nice Peroni or Moretti to wash it down.  Their coffee isn't bad either.
author: David H.

description: This is one of my favorite lunch spots. Always great sandwiches, the  meatball is my favorite.  Service is always friendly. Always a welcoming place
author: Dilly M.

description:
Get the eggplant sandwich, the breaded one. My friends & I have been going here for, holy crap, almost 20 yrs just for that. Grab a table looking out on Washington Square. 

Then maybe walk up Columbus for some truffles from XOX. A good place to meet friends for lunch on a rainy day. Or a sunny day. Or a non-sunny night.
author: A H.

description:
Now, if you want a great panini sandwich this is where to go. 
The sandwiches on foccacia bread are the best with a tall glass of Stella beer. 
Above all, the best we delight ourselves in is .... the grilled 
"Eggplant" sandwich. 
Their salads are good but not as good as Mocca Cafe. 

Coffee "Cappuccino's are THE BEST!! 
Dessert's are soooo good and made homemade.  Try the Ricotta Cheesecake and not to mention the Coffee Cake.
The Merlot house wine is not good. The wine selections are just ok. 
They have great music playing loud and they change it often.

Yes, it is a small place but you won't regret it.
The service is kinda a slow and yes it depends who's working the shift.
For two people, about $35.00 to $40.00.
This is way better than Mocca Cafe, still I love those tri tip sandwiches.
Remember, you are getting the best quality homemade everything. 
I just love Mario's, We treat ourselves so often there. 

I love these places 'coz I make these at home and just as tasty, thats why I find it worth spending your hard earned $ for what you pay when you do dine out ...... it has to be GOOD!!
author: Taylor W.

description:
Cigars . . . No. . . Good eats. . . yes sir
Simple, yet just what the doctor ordered. We stopped at Mario's for lunch on a beautiful Sunday afternoon, post walking around North Beach all morning. The place is simple, and tight, with about 6 tables along the windows and then a counter overlooking the small kitchen, boom, that's it.  The guys were great on the service! The atmosphere is quaint and super friendly. The three of us split up a Chicken #2 panini, and the (man this was good!) eggplant panini. They were both great sandwiches. As commented by others, no sides here, just your sandwich. But, you know what, I didn't care! We three left completely satisfied. The focaccia bread was wonderful and fresh, the veggies seasoned and cooked excellently, and the chicken and the eggplant, nicely seasoned (eggplant was breaded).
For a quick stop to a local shop, I definitely recommend Mario's, for a bite to eat in an old world location. And, don't be afraid to ask the boys about their coffees. They know about their coffees.
author: Greg S.

description: My first visit to Mario's was in '04 -- a friend of mine and I were overwhelmed by the number of Italian places to try in NB and somehow out of all of them we ended up stumbling upon this gem right smack on the corner of all the action.  This place is a bona fide Italian cafe -- the espresso machine is sputtering non-stop and the waiters are scrambling between taking orders, serving food, and brewing espresso.  The meatball sandwich was amaaaazing.  So fresh and so tasty I'd be hard pressed to find one better.  We also met a local here who was kind enough to show us around NB and said Mario's is the best Italian in all of North Beach - all the other places like Steps of Rome are tourist traps.  We ended up hanging out the rest of the weekend.  Love Marios, and whenever I come back to SF I will be sure to return here!
author: Jen C.

description: Did not have a meal here, but I did have a delicious espressso made with love and care by an expert barista.   I believe the man had a moustache with the ends turned up.  What a sweetheart. We sat at our table for a long time and were never hassled to get up to make way for the diners.  The music was fantastic.  I intend to go back for a meal.
author: Bleep S.

description:
20 years living near here and I've worshipped the meat ball or the sausage foccacia panini.  Endless flavor and just the right slightly blackened crispness from the tiny oven.  Last 2 panini I've had here were REALLY disappointing  -- somethin's changed.  Still a great location and room, but I sure miss the meat ball and sausage panini of yore.  Hasn't anyone else noticed this?

Since my bout of negativity, I've been back to Mario's 3 times.  The foccacia panini are a lot more credible, if not back to their glory days.  Maybe the oven was broken, since the foccacia is crisp and hot again.
author: William H.

description:
we happened upon this place by tring to get some food off mason, we ran into a sports bar that had no food but the bouncer told us about marios and how they had the best meatball sandwich in town.  i am not a fan of meatball sandwiches but it was a good enough recommendation and we decided to give it a shot.  

we were impressed, very good paninni sandwiches and the staff was very nice, a little gruff looking especially the cat with the dirty dreads and the french accent, but it was worth overlooking.  

only complaint is they didnt have any chips or fries and i like me some  crunchy with my sandwich but besides that it was very nice.

peroni beer very good, expect some old scratchie glasses doe.
author: dash s.

description:
A nice little spot near the greenery of Washington Square; perfect for catching the last sun of the day while sipping on a cold beer and munching on a petite slice of pizza.

Very shifting quality among their personnel though: sometimes service is good, sometimes service can be straight up horrible/non-existent.
author: Pastor Z.

description: Really good service.  That can make up for a lot of mistakes, but there were no mistakes at Mario's and we still got really good service.  Great vibe to the place and a great location for people watching.  Sit down, have a pint, enjoy a great meal and watch things unfold in the park.
author: Corey V.

description: I loved this place. We only went in for a cup of coffee but the experience was great. The cakes looked amazing. My favorite part was the 2 servers behind the bar. They were hilarious (you know who you are handle bar stache). Plus the latte was amazing, best I had had in years.
author: Laurie A.

description: Toasted sandwiches made from Liguria foccacia are dreamy.  They're the dreamiest when you've been wandering hungrily within a 1-mile radius of North Beach and want a seat and a dinner that's in no way a big production.  Barstool, beer, bohemian eggplant & mozzarella.
author: Erin K.

description: Mario's worked so well as a coffee break stop on my last walking tour that I decided to promote it to lunch stop this time around.  Which is another way of saying that I was dying to come back and try the much-Yelped focaccia sandwiches (actually, the grilled veggie focaccia is open-faced, meaning it's really more of a pizza, but it's frankly less messy this way, and still crispy-chewy, oiled-to-golden-glory and 100% drool-worthy).
author: Wes M.

description: Grilled eggplant foccacia sandwich. OH.MY.GOD. 'Nuff said.
author: T T.

description: 5* for Elizabeth and Brian's lovely Festivus party here! Look forward to coming back to see what they serve in this charming little annex of a cafe.
author: Jon F.

description:
what can i say?  this place is across from one of the most active parks in one of the most beautiful parts of the city. you are bound to have a good time (especially when sunny) here.

food is good.  small, but just right to get a good feel and service. a lot of gawking can be done inside and out!  beers on tap are good.
author: Ryan M.

description: Such a warm and enticing little North Beach spot! I spent a rainy Sunday afternoon just hanging out here and loved it! Good beer, food and coffee. Great views of Columbus St. and Washington Square Park. The small space, with lack of tv's, makes the place pleasantly comfortable and homey.
author: Stephanie J.

description:
First thing, don't go there expecting cigars.

The food is fantastic, if a little expensive ($8 for a sandwich).  Meatball and balsamic chicken foccacia sandwiches are personal favorites.

Outdoor seating is nice, just make sure you're sitting directly in the sun.

A great place to take friends from out of town or to have lunch in between Washington Square Park hangouts.
author: Tif S.

description: Mario's is typically not a place I would have tried in SF but our favorite bartender at Vesuvio's recommended it when asked where can we get a good sandwich.  The name alone (containing Cigar) would have been enough to make me think not.  Food and smoke don't settle well with me unless we are talking BBQ.  Asking a local is always a good idea because you usually end up with great food at inexpensive prices.  Mario's was one of those places.  Don't overlook Mario's, give it a try, you will be pleasantly surprised.
author: Dianne M.

description: Best focaccia sandwiches, great espresso, and a variety of beers and wines. Good music. Hip spot, and lovely view of WA Square Park with Sts. Peter & Paul in the background. Been coming here since the old man owned in and the place was full of cigar-smoking men parlando italiano!
author: Geoffrey B.

description: I LOVE this place!  My husband brought me here on one of our dates and we always go back to it when we go to the City.  The owner is very nice!
author: C T.

description:
very, very good coffee (graffeo).  i really like this place; it's authentic and no-nonsense.  it's not stupidly expensive like most places in sf.  some of the people who work here will speak italian with you and not make fun of your j.v. language skills.

tosta.
author: kimb s.

description: Really good panini sandwiches. I loved the accompanying pepperoncini's. Small, cozy place - very cool.
author: Scott J.

description: I am not into cigars or bars, but someone introduced me to Mario's long, long ago, and I have been a fan ever since. Consider this great comfort food. I am a fan of the hot foccacia sandwiches. I've had veggie and breaded eggplant. I get one or the other and have been for the last twelve years. Sometimes I think of trying something else, but I am worried the eggplant will miss me. On my last visit, I sat at the counter for the first time (usually I'm at the small table in back) and enjoyed watching the food being made. Kudos to the sandwich makers!
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Despite the unappetizing name, the sandwiches here are good, especially the eggplant or meatball panini. Add a cold beer and you have a very filling lunch.
author: Michael R.

description: I love this place - whenever I am in San Francisco, Mario's is like my compass. I have found myself on a barstool eating an eggplant focaccia panini and drinking some house wine several times and I couldn't have been happier.  Falling into Mario's is like leaving 21st century earth and landing into 1974 (as I imagine it).  It just feels right.  Oh, hey, and their bathroom ~ you will never visit another one like it, I promise...
author: melissa m.

description: In need of a solid panini? This is the place to hit. I had the mozerella, tomato and basil pesto panini and it was scrumpcious! Grilled to perfection and hit the spot after a sweet workout. This place is a cool little spot. Not too big and every table including the bar area was full.
